Almost as an act of defiance against encroaching obsolescence, the manor house, stood proud amidst a wildscape of mist-enshrouded oaks and dark lilac heath, echoing its mistress' imperious solitude. Nestled under the manorâ€™s weather-beaten eaves, laughter was scant and merriment echoed softly, as if caring not to disturb the delicate equilibrium of resigned melancholy that twirled slow waltzes within every chamber, every whispering corridor. The rumours were ripe with spectres from the past, whispering lamentations through the decaying fabric of the home, but Cordelia Fairfax, with her keen eyes echoing the iron-grey skies, paid little heed to the whispers of spectral conscience, for her battles were fought with the living, under the guise of composure, in the arena of unsulled silence.
author: bronte

text: Amid the windswept moors of northern England, where brutal winters crept into the very marrow of one's bones and fierce, unrestrained summers turned the barren landscape into a riotous, wild palette of colors, lay the imposing figure of Thornfield Hall. It stood stern and grim, mute witness of countless yesterdays, its ancient stones weathered by time, yet resilient, firm against the relentless assault of the elements. Within its hallowed walls pulsed the heartbeat of life, shadows and stories, dreams and despair weaving a rich tapestry of human passions and secrets. Its tall, dark windows peered out like watchful eyes onto the wild expanse of the moors, their glass as old as the flickering ghost stories whispered into the eager ears of young Earls on cold, stormy nights. Here dwelt Miss Elizabeth Hastings, a creature of intense spirit and gentle humility, whose misfortunes had not dimmed her fervor for life, nor the incandescent flame of hope that warmed her heart. Such was the nature of this solitary estate, an emblem of stern beauty amidst the wild, untamed wilderness of God's country.
author: bronte

text: In the crumbling manor of Grievehart, there resided a singularly obstinate woman, Miss Elinor Harcourt. Stern of mien and sharp of tongue, she bore a constitution cultivated by years spent in solitude and a mind sharpened by a rigorous education, rarely seen in a woman of her time. The tapestry of her life was threaded with the richest of silks, yet woven into the fabric of her existence were strands of sorrow, feathers of lost love, and the cruelly indelible ink of betrayal. Yet, she held her head high, a beacon of self-reliance in an ocean of societal expectation, an oil painting of fierce femininity under the patriarchal sky. Outside, the wild moors whispered, mimicking her spirit - untamed and indomitable. This brave vessel, astride the turbulent waves of life's capricious ocean, could navigate the labyrinthine labyrinth of life and emerge unscathed, her spirit luminous amidst the bleak mist of adversity.
author: bronte

text: In the quiet, somber vestiges of Thornfield Manor, resided a sentiment of untold stories. The high, weathered walls, wearing an embroidery of ivy that had thrived over countless seasons, whispered secret echoes to the wind - odd tales of love and loss that had once filled its chambers with a different, vibrant life. Each antique piece of furniture stood, silent and stolid, covered in delicate layers of woven history. How each crack in the wooden staircase and each faded tapestry held testament to the long passages of time. Behind the gloom of unseen corners and throughout the labyrinthine corridors, the Manor was imbued with a character unspoken, yet palpable - a silent observer, a haunted protagonist that wove the story of mankind with an eerie eloquence that only Miss Bronte could pen. It was as if the very stones held the unwept tears and the joyous laughters accumulated over centuries, holding them close to their cold, lifeless hearts. Here, even sorrow was a gracious guest and happiness was limited like ephemeral sunshine that teasingly played peekaboo through the towering oaks before being swallowed by the perennial grey of the Northern shires.
author: bronte

text: In the hushed twilight hours, nestled amongst Yorkshire's craggy moors, stood the old parsonage, a demure monument to simplicity and grace. Its ancient stone faÃ§ade bore silent witness to countless seasons, each marked by the ebb and flow of life's tributes and trials. Honeysuckle vines, unbridled in their wild abandon, clung with tenacity to the generations-old masonry, flourishing under the weather-beaten kisses of the northern wind. The silent gravel path leading to the heavy oak door bore the weary tracks of dear reminiscence, a pedestrian sonnet written in the dust. Inside, stories lived and breathed, falling like soft whispers from the family portraits adorning the aged walls. The soft murmur of life flowed through the parlors, a tender accompaniment to the stanzas of time, which like a dedicated scribe, penned its rhymes of living within the folds of the parsonage, under the watchful grey skies of BrontÃ« Country.
author: bronte

text: In the solitary locale of Thornfield Manor, nestled amid the broad and verdant landscape of Yorkshire, resided the gentle yet somber Rebecca Fontaine, a governess of delicate constitution but staunch resolve. Though her days were often populated with austere Latin verbs and tedious French prose, her true delight was in the quiet hours of night, when she could partake of her clandestine passions for philosophy and poetry. Her company, for the most part, consisted of the chilly stone walls and ghostly tapestries of the imposing manor, alongside the unspoken secrets that they shrouded. Yet, within her dwelled a fiery spirit, an untamable vitality that wrestled against the confines of her social station and found its answers in the wild fury of the gales that swept across the heathâ€”winds that were as kindred spirits, free and unshackled, whispering secrets of far-off places and new beginnings. Thusly, amidst the seeming monotony and seclusion, Rebecca's world was a riot of repressed emotions and unfettered dreams.
author: bronte

text: In the dim, hushed hours of the somber morning, a light was borne from the window of an aging edifice nested within the moors. The lamplight flickered feebly, casting long, quivering shadows upon the dew-kissed heath. It gave pause to but a singular figure, drained of vigor, a semblance of a woman weighed heavily by her years. Inside, her heart writhed with a grief as unyielding as the stone walls surrounding her. Her gaze was ironbound to an old, threadbare shawl, the last memento of her lost love. It held the echoes of laughter, whispers, and shared dreams, now faded, leaving a silence as stark and daunting as the midnight moors themselves. The shawl, though frayed by the cruel hand of time, was a constant reminder of the flames of passion that once roared within their hearts, now reduced to spectral embers in the haunting recess of memory. And so, the woman endured, every sigh a lament for her lost love, every beat of her heart a testament to her solitude within the desolate and unforgiving landscape that was her soul's reflection.
author: bronte

text: In the elegiac silence of Thornfield Manor, our heroine, Miss Isabella Hartley, found herself wrapped in the melancholy embrace of the ancient, ghostly halls, as intimately bound to them as the creeping ivy was to the worn stones. The heavy oak door creaked its familiar woeful tune behind her, sighing with years of secrets contained within its timeworn grain. Lit only by the wan silver moonlight spilling carelessly into the room from a singular broken window, her modest figure stood stark against ancestral portraits, their faces etched with the same stoic sorrows that seemed confined within these historic walls. Though the chill of the English winter bore down upon the old manor unmercifully, a fiery ambition smouldered in her resolute hazel eyes as she steeled herself for the trials to come. Like the resilient wildflower persistently flowering through the frost, Miss Hartley thrived amidst adversity, each challenge serving only to strengthen her resolve. The echoes of hushed voices from bygone eras whispered stories of resilience and courage to her, and she resolved to add her own tale to this timeless symphony.
author: bronte

text: Observe a solitary figure traversing the windswept moors, the sable tendrils of her hair dancing with the untamed gusts, her coat whipping about her as though mirroring the inner tumult of her soul. Her name is Eleanor, a creature of uninhibited spirit and fierce independence. She draws solace from nature's raw might, in the capricious weather, in the starkness of the wild heathland, stark echoes of her own fiery heart. If one were to perceive her as a hapless damsel, they would be sorely mistaken, for Eleanor is a heroine in her own uncelebrated epic, writ amidst the boundless billows of the moors, and the deepest chambers of her resilient heart.
author: bronte

text: As the mottled shades of the twilight cascaded over the solitary Manor, our heroine, Miss Guinevere Austell, found herself entranced by the solitude of the rolling English moors that spread out before her like a emerald sea. She stood at the severe edge of propriety, her heart riddled with a special kind of melancholy reserved for those who have known both loveâ€™s dizzying heights and its inevitable despair. Hers was a strength that had been hard-earned; her loneliness turned into a virtue more appreciated by her spirit than by her society. A woman of singular intelligence and heart, her sharp wit was often mistaken for sharp edges, a complexity misunderstood by many in this harsh and baroque world of defined roles. The outstretched moors, under the purpling sky of the setting sun, seemed like the only witness to her solitude and potential, their everlasting silence like solidarity against an unyieldingly stoic Victorian society.
author: bronte

text: Etienne, a man of equal parts enigma and charm, lived cloistered in the secluded estate of Clairmont Manor, nestled in the brooding heathlands of northern England. His countenance, possessing a melodramatic mix of sullen defiance and disarming gentleness not unlike the tempestuous moorland winds themselves, seemed forever corroborated by the melancholic roll of the weeping willows in the mansion's gardens. The chamberâ€™s crimson draperies, licking at the furniture like a fervent blaze, dimly echoed the consuming passion that often held him prisoner. Yet an ambient moonlight cooed him lovingly from his private torment, pirouetting across his ancient manuscripts and forgotten music scores, wooing him into an enchanting waltz of maiden daylight and mistress night. As the years floated by with stolid indifference, time seemed to leave an imperceptible tattoo on his soul, crafting a man who was as much a caricature of gnarled, untamed wilderness as he was a symphony of desperate yearning and silent resistance.
author: bronte

text: In the soft gloaming of dusk, fair and pale Clarissa rested her forlorn eyes on the sprawling landscape, her heart echoing with a lonesomely ethereal echo among the dusty tapestries of Rochester Manor. The mirthful boughs of the venerable oaks in the distance playfully tousled in the mellow whispers of the summer zephyrs, and the soft breath of the hauntingly beautiful rose gardens carried with them a melancholy poignancy, a relic of hallowed, forgotten yesterdays. Her delicate fingers traced an abstract path along the age-worn balustrade, her thoughts a languid ballet, attempting fleetingly to escape the tightened corset of societal expectation and tradition - yearning for the intoxicating elixir of liberation, as elusive as the final flickers of dying embers reaching out to the obsidian night.
author: bronte

text: With evening's arrival, a gentle hush descended upon Thornfield Hall. Flickering candles scattered ghostly shapes across paneled walls as even the relentless North Yorkshire winds appeared subdued. Miss Eyre, our severe yet tender heroine, found herself anchored near the fireplace, it's hearth shedding a warm glow across her intricate needlework. Outside, the moon gilded darkened meadows, and age-old oak trees quivered in the chill, their spectral shapes whispering tales of years past. As she sighed in the tranquility of the moment, time itself seemed to halt, standing ever so respectful of her quiet respite. Yet, in the stark silence, memories seeped in - memories of distant laughter, hushed conversation, and stolen glances, every remembrance bringing with it a tumult of indescribable emotion.
author: bronte

text: In the gloaming hour, nestled in the brooding landscape that seemed to sweep all around her, stood the old Wyndham Manor; its stony visage etching an imposing silhouette against the rosy-tinged tapestry of the waning sun. Ivy had begun its slow siege upon the edifice, shrouding it in a somber green cloak which only added to the structure's mystic aura. Within the Manor, our heroine, Eleanor, paced anxiously from fireplace to frigid window, her heart a tumultuous sea of nervous anticipation. Outside, the wind moaned a spectral lullaby, capricious as Eleanor's fate. She clutched at the locket hanging from her pale throat, a final memento of tender youth, her fingers trembling as she opened it to reveal the miniature painted portrait of a woman, her visage radiant with undefeatable resolve. Her mother. The one beacon guiding her through the storm that now threatened to consume her entire existence.
author: bronte

text: In a remote corner of England, where hills soared high and valleys dipped low, cradled a quaint hamlet which was, to those who stumbled upon it, a respite from the world's relentless hubbub. A picturesque village, hemmed in by the wild beauty of undulating moors and punctuated by a tranquil, meandering brook - Ardent Hollow. Its humble cottages, shrouded in creeping ivy, were habitation to souls simple yet profound. Nestled amongst them, dwarfed by the ancient oaks, sat a singular dwelling, a parsonage by the name of Hallow House. Within its time-worn walls, was harbored a medley of dreams and despair, of wisdom and folly, of agony and ecstasy - the bricolage of humanity sewed into the tapestry of life. This mÃ©lange played out its drama under the ever-watchful, ever-judgmental gaze of Providence, transfixed like a silent spectator in the unbroken firmament above.
author: bronte

text: Upon the moor, under the shadow of the old abbey, stood a solitary figure, consumed by a quiet solitude of its own making. Miss Hargreaves, her mind a tempest hidden beneath the calm facade of politeness, turned her gaze towards the far-reaching expanse, a sight that echoed the vastness of her inward sorrow. Her heart beat in rhythm with the song of unseen larks, her thoughts as wild and untamed as the wind which tugged earnestly at her dark, robust curls. The world lay before her, a tableau of grief and beauty, stark in its honesty. As twilight descended over the wild countryside, so too did it descend upon the labyrinth of her private musings, casting long somber shadows that spoke of sorrows past and hinted at sorrows yet to come. The world, both internal and external, seemed to be mirroring the quiet persistence of her spirit, humbling in its grandeur and ineffable in its mystery. Yet in that solitude, Miss Hargreaves imagined the blooming of a fragile hope, like heather breaking through the cracked earth, a testament to the improbable resilience of life and love.
author: bronte

text: In the quietude of Thornfield Manor, where shadows gathered in grim corners and lined the heavy oak-panelled hallways with whispers of another age, a delicate harmony pervailed that softly echoed in the heart of our pensive heroine. Miss Adele, the new governess, with her hair like spun gold and eyes reflecting the serenity of a summer's pond, emboldened herself in the rigours of her duty assiduously; she touched every inch of her responsibility with a tender gentility and absorbing grace. Her world, though confined to the solemnity and antiquity of the Manor, pulsed with a lustrous vitality, born of her inner strength and eloquence. Illuminated by the warm glow of candlelight, every ebony shadow that draped her solitary room, every hushed whisper of the ancient bildings, conspired in concert, composing a melancholic symphony that was hers and hers alone. Oh, how she yearned for a life beyond these stone confines! Yet, with a heart generous in courage and a spirit undaunted in resilience, she embraced her present existence, a testament to her peculiar strength and indomitable will.
author: bronte

text: Upon the isolated, windswept moor stood a house, The Heathfields, its ivy-clad facades imbued with a certain gloomy grandeur, forever battling the chastising gusts that echoed upon the ancient stones. As I approached the domicile, where I, Miss Marguerite Westwood, unmarried and recently orphaned, was doomed to serve as governess, I could not help but shudder. A pall of dread seemed to blanketed the hills and hollows like a spectral fog. The solitude of my existence shrieked with greater desolation upon sight of this fortress of stone. The house, unfeeling and unwelcoming, was like time itself, stolidly standing against the world's onslaught, unyielding to its fate, bearing the burdens and secrets of generations past and present within its cold walls. Yet, upon embarking on this chapter of my life, little did I foresee the storm of passion and despair that was soon to engorge the solemn edifice.
author: bronte

text: In the secluded hamlet of Brooding Heath, beneath the severe gaze of the immutable North Moors, the parsonage stood with unwavering resilience. Shrouded in the chill winds of uncanny prophecy, through rooms affording no more warmth than the loveless winter, wandered our dear Miss Eugenia. Her eyes, liquid pools of blithe curiosity, traced the barren scenes of a familiar life â€“ obstinately unchanged, disappointing in their steadfast obedience to routine. The air thrummed with an intense quietude that only heightened her sense of solitary exile. The austere beauty of the landscape, the haunting silence, all seemed to inform her heartâ€™s peculiar language, forging from each beat a wordless poem, penned in the acclaimed ink of melancholy. Yet she bore this somber sonnet with a grace and fortitude beyond her tender years, each step a determined verse towards a future composed under her own accords.
author: bronte

text: Upon the desolate moor, beneath a steel grey sky, nestled a hamlet as quaint as an unspoken verse. Gnarled trees stood sentinel: stoic guardians of an ancient landscape, their leaves rustling softly, whispering secrets of yesteryears into the chilled air. Homes once vibrant, now stood forlorn and hushed, chimneys silently reaching for the heavens, like desperate prayers incarnate. Somewhere a raven croaked, a solitary elegy to the forgotten serenity of the rustic morn. Time, in its patient fortitude, had washed over this place with a melancholic tenderness, painting its tale with hues of silence and wind-kissed sorrow. This was nature, raw yet gentle, fierce yet healing, a place where breath and heartbeat were the notes to an eternal symphony. It was, in its very essence, life etched in stone and soil, a tale spun in cloud and shadow by an inconspicuous weaver.
author: bronte

text: Beneath the whaler-grey sky, the moor stretched, a tempestuous tapestry of brooding heather and windswept grass, rolling hill meeting sunken dale in tumultuous union. It was a kingdom unto itself, a callous sovereign filled with wild delight in its own forbidding grandeur. Upon the crest of a lonesome knoll, a figure stood â€”a mere wraith amidst the overwhelming majesty of nature, every fiber of her being resonating with the untamed beauty about her. Miss Hatherway was not a woman of conventional charm, but in her heart bore a capacity for feeling as boundless as the moor itself. She danced on the precipice of tender melancholy and bold resilience, each emotion wielded with the indomitable strength of those who bear no pretension of insensibility. The lyrical wind whispered tales of solitude and freedom, weaving golden threads of hope through the stony grey of her existence, promising a future painted in hues brighter than the staunch tints that hemmed her current world.
author: bronte

text: In the breach of dawn, under the soft, melancholy light, the manse of Thornfield stoodâ€”its tall, sturdy stones braving the years, the winds, the rains like a lonely but steadfast sentinel. A memento of silent histories, it loomed over the hedge-ringed moor, holding its stoic vigilance against the unyielding march of time. The vast expanse of its venerable face was specked with the verdant of climbing ivy, an unruly shroud augmenting its spectral grandeur. Long fingered shadows, cast by the eldritch moonlight, clung to its weather-beaten edifice in a poignant embrace, promising the day's impending shade. The desolate cries of the wind whistled through the ancient trees that complied with a weathered hum of leaves rustling in obedient concert. Though many a weary soul might find the sight forbidding, in this fortress of stone shrouded by the veil of the early morn, there existed an austere charm, a symphony of old world romance with a poignant reminder of the immutable resonance of existence.
author: bronte

text: Indeed the storm was but a fitting preclude to the tumultuous tempest flourishing within the labyrinth of my own bosom. The fen ahead, enshrouded in a thick cloak of haze, began to vanish from my sight, so too did my previous existence. I am not a woman of the past; nay, I am one who, even in the tumult of hardship, seeks not providence, but perseverance. The bleak and somber skies speak not despair to me, but strength. For it is in the bleakness that one learns to seek their own light, and it is in the storm that we become incapable of ignoring the steady rhythm of our own hearts. Henceforth, I am determined. Not by the course dictated by society or status, but by the unyielding tide of my own convictions; a resolute beacon against the howling winds of fate.
author: bronte

text: The day beheld itself sombre and dull, the sky shrouded in a tapestry of grey, casting long somber shadows across the landscape. In the quiet seclusion of Thornfield Hall resided a creature of lively spirit and vivacious intellect trapped by circumstance, a bird ensnared in a gilded cage. I speak of Miss Adele Fairfax, the ward of the enigmatic Mr. Rochester, who peered at the world outside with eyes possessing an inquisitive sparkle. She encompassed that youthful purity, which adult life, marked by sorrow and disappointment, often neglects. The world to her was yet a canvas unblemished, ripe with opportunities for adventure and discovery. As she meandered in the gardens, surrounded by the succinct hush of nature, her heart whispered silent stories, her imagination painted pictures of dance, song, and revelry, offering a colourful contrast to the subdued world around her. Her spirit was yet untouched by the sorrow of the world, a beacon of hope in a world overcast with despair.
author: bronte

text: In the quiet hamlet of Thornfield, overshadowed by a darkened woodland and nestled under the gloomy embrace of the North Yorkshire moors, lived our heroine, Miss Eleanor Hayward. A creature of humble origins and benign aspirations, Eleanor, despite her delicate, pale countenance, possessed a spirit imbued with a quixotic blend of resilience and hazel-eyed ambition. Beyond the realms of her humble abode, in the unvisited rooms of her secretive disposition, Eleanor danced with dreams that no village dialect could adequately articulate. She cherished a steadfast hunger for knowledge and yearned for adventures beyond her immediate comprehension, much akin to the twisting trails disappearing into the undulating moors surrounding her environment. Thus, she sat by her tiny casement every twilight, eyes tracing the edges of the undulating horizon, her mind a flurry of unvoiced desires and unscripted fantasies. There, by the whispering sibilance of the heather in the breeze and the broken melody of the Sparrow's farewell song, our heroine dreamt of the life she dared to live.
author: bronte

text: Upon the desolate moors, obscured by a curtain of weeping mist, stoic stood an old manor house, its once grand faÃ§ade now weathered and worn by time. Despite the morose chill that the north wind brought, tendrils of warmth stemmed from the house's ancient chimney, weaving an illusion of comfort amidst such melancholia. Its dilapidated form bore an uncanny resemblance to the land's brooding disposition. Candle light could be seen flickering restlessly in the attic window, like the fading consciousness of a reclusive resident, staring out into the encroaching gloom, yearning for a time lost to the unstoppable march of days.
author: bronte

text: In the twilight hour, nestled betwixt the hoary hills of Yorkshire, lay a manor house, Thornfield Heights, replete with secrets as vast of the universe itself. Ivy trailed up its stone walls, walls that have borne witness to the passage of countless seasons, to happiness and melancholy alike. Silhouetted against the placid English sky, its windows stood, a silent vigil to the ancient order of days past, their proud ghosts refusing to dim. Within these venerable walls, there resided a peculiar fellow, Mr. Rochester. A solitary figure prowling his ancestral halls, his countenance ever bearing the weight of a hidden pain, his eyes, somber, concealing the deep oceans of torment roiling beneath the surface. Every time the wind wailed through the whispering trees, it seemed to echo the lament that rode perpetually in his heart. He was not forsaken to this isolated existence utterly, however: the flickers of light did pierce through such gloom, and they bore the name Jane Eyre.
author: bronte

text: The evening swept over Thornton Hall with a melody of whispering winds and distant church bells. Miss Agnes, with her raven-black curls and grey-blue eyes aglow with the light of a thousand forgotten stars, sat in her beloved sanctuary, the grand library. Shadows danced across the towering shelves, swept in from the cold by the fire's vague, creepings of gentle light; echoes of stories long buried were etched in every thread of the olden Persian rug. As under her delicate fingers the viridian leather spine of a weathered volume bent and sighed; the echo of a faded world came to life. Her heart oddly synchronous with the slow, curling tendrils of smoke that rose from the dimming pine firelogs, striving for an unreachable height, only to dissipate like the vestiges of a sanguine dream. This was solitude, she thought. However, there was no melancholy in her gaze, but rather, a perverse joy - a quiet triumph. This solitude was not a curse, but her freedom, her sanctuary, her universe. This was her tranquil defiance against the world's stingingly mundane expectations of what a woman's life should be - Agnes, in this moment, was living the only truth she knew and required. Her universe was in books, her life's passion scribed in the margins of well-loved pages, and her spirit? That was as boundless as the stories she devoured and as fathomless as the inked seas they sailed.
author: bronte

text: Our protagonist, Miss Eliza Harrington, harbored a heart ensnared by bewitching perplexities, in the quiet hamlet of Arlingford. This morning, the fog-laden moors were basking in an ethereal glow as she glimpsed out of the frost-etched window pane, her porcelain fingers clutching a cup of slowly cooling tea. The silent hills beyond were as forlorn as her spirit, burdened with sentiments unexpressed and hopes yet undiscovered. A deft flicker of the candle teased the edges of her diary, eliciting a contour of secrets that dared only whisper in the dim light, much akin to the cryptic contrivances of her own heart. For in the quiet solitude of her room, Eliza found herself tangled in an intricate embroidery of foreign emotions, emotions begotten by Mr. Charles Fairfax, the town's charismatic yet enigmatic roamer. As such, a dance of passion and peculiar trepidations took place within her, undecipherable fulgurations looming in the horizon of her world, waiting to break the tranquility of her maidenhood.
author: bronte

text: In the somber cradle of Thornfield Hall, night leaned heavy with a quietude that was almost damnable. Suffered by the hush, the moon - old and staid, loftily presided over the dark heavens, casting a slender quill of silver light upon the lambent mansion. There emerged a profound solace yet an uncanny mystery in the solitude, painting restless pictures on my mindâ€™s canvas. Ay! The house seemed like another great beast; noir, unidentified yet majestic, hardworking in its silence, effectually concealing scripts of brooding secrets. Simultaneous fear and fascination drew me hither, paralysing reason and awakening curiosity within my heart, evoking a fervid ardor to tease the clandestine yarns haunting those stone walls into narration. For who ought not want to romp in the exhaustive mysteries of such a place? Indeed, dear reader, mystery bespeaks temptation and temptation, in its own sweet sin, is the iron anchor that yokes us to the advent of exploration.
author: bronte

text: Against the canvas of a leaden sky, a stark ghost-like manor stood like a hulking sentinel guarding secrets of epochs past. Twisted fingers of bare trees reached out to it in a spectral dance, their desolate grace reflected in the silent attentions of the ever observant, ever vigilant Northumberland moor. A stubborn wind, loyal to the whims of the tempestuous weather, wandered erratically, now murmuring secrets to the craggy stones and now whispering melancholy sonnets in the ears of the last remaining heather. Yet, amidst the unwelcoming tableau, there was a resolute warmth glowing, a defiant spark hiding in the flickering candlelight streaming from a lonely frosted glass window. Yes, dear reader, there nestled within the brooding, ever daunting facade, thrived the indomitable spirit of our heroine, a lighthouse challenging the storm, a poem refusing to be silenced by the winter's maw.
author: bronte

text: In the latter part of an autumn day, as the sun gradually surrendered its reign to the encroaching night, the moors of Yorkshire were bathed in an ethereal splendour of crimson and gold. A solitary manor stood adamant as sentinel amidst nature's vast expanse. Within, silent walls whispered tales of yore while spectral shadows danced on aged wooden panels. The lonely spirit of the house, Miss Hester, retired to her favourite corner by the fire, ensconced in her father's time-worn armchair. Nestled in the flickering glow, her pale countenance mirrored stories of loss and love echoed in each creak an old floorboard surrendered, each gust howling through the skeletal branches of an ancient oak. Fragments of her shattered past, the heartaches of time had mechanized into routine, encircling her life. Over the course of years, Hester had constructed a fortress of solitude around herself, rendering her spirit impenetrable to the transient afflictions of the world. She was a living chronicle that breathed the quintessence of Bronte's England - a testament to the timeless resilience of a life weathered, but unshaken.
author: bronte

text: Concealed beneath the protective veil of the ancient, gnarled chestnut tree, Miss Eleanor Everhart watched with quietly mounting consternation. Her usually placid countenance betraying a hint of storm-clouded worry as she observed the distant silhouette of Hollowgate Manor. The manor, once the epitome of unshakeable, aristocratic grandeur, now appeared as a diminished vessel of former glory, with its stone facades weathered by lamentations of North winds and cruel winters. A lone raven perched on its roofted tower, giving off an eerie caw, just as the wind howled a mournful echo through the high crevices of the moss-draped walls. Each room, she fancied, held a ghost of its own, playing scenes of stirring dramas of days long past with an aurora of melancholic resonance. As tender as maidenâ€™s heart, as strong as widowâ€™s reflection, such was Hollowgate Manor - an effigy of histories forsaken and memories persisting. And though it stood, greyed and crumbling, the manor held a forceful essence in its silence that still reverberated through the heart of the Yorkshire moors.
author: bronte

text: In the quiet recesses of my heart, beneath the shadow of an old oak, sanctity claimed its refuge. The fresh and verdant meadow spoke of peace; the gentle rustle of leaves whispered ancient secrets. The sun, in its half-somber, half-playful mood, gleefully sent down chance rays to dance upon the leaves. Fallen crumbs of bird-song adorned the silken pockets of the air and all seemed in fair contentment. How the illusion beguiled! For without warning, mood turned as fickle as dreams. And the sun, gleaming once with warmth and promise, now hid its radiant visage behind thick veils of grey. The wind, a playful friend but moments ago, transformed into a sinister foe, whispering unspeakable tales of desolation. Reminiscent of the human condition, I mused, a heart brimming with joy in one fleeting moment can so easily sink into the cold grip of sorrow the next, a tempestuous sea under a deceitful sky.
author: bronte

text: The solitary dwelling, nestled amidst the desolate moors, stood as resolute as an unbending martyr. Grey, gnarled stones stood piled one atop the other, a testament to its longevityâ€”a sentinel against the untamed gales that whistled through the hinterland. Ivy ran wild in tendrils across its stern faÃ§ade, yet each cold window stared blankly out onto the rustling wilderness. It was an edifice possessing strength borne out of its seclusion, a monument to the enduring spirit of all those who sought solitude in the vast, vacant surroundings. A whiff of the chimneypot smoke curled and danced into the leaden sky, weaving tales of its occupant's living spirit amidst the austere, quiet desolation around.
author: bronte

text: Upon the isolated hills of Yorkshire, amidst a weather-worn edifice of stone and mortality, dwelt the noble Ashton family, guardians of the antiquated traditions enshrined within its austere halls. The echoes of a gale swept across the wuthering landscape, a desolate symphony enhancing the ethereal beauty of the heaths, as if lending voice to the secrets ensnared over generations. Lady Constance, the last scion of the house, could oftentimes be found contemplating within the chambers of the house, her eyes mirroring the tempestuous kaleidoscope of her soul, wrestling with her duty and desires - a tableau of unvoiced sentiments etched in the canvas of her countenance. The pervading silence was incessantly punctuated by the resounding tick-tock of the ancient grandfather clock, a relentless reminder of the transience of existence, each beat a summons closer towards the inevitable embrace of oblivion.
author: bronte

text: In the tranquil seclusion of Thornfield Manor, beneath the graceful arches of ancient willows echoing the inaudible hymn of the past, walked a woman, not ethereal but imbued with a quiet strength that whispered of many storms weathered. Her countenance, although as gentle as morning mist, held an indefinable flame, the kind which could make a cascade of even the stoutest hearts. Her fingers traced the edges of mouldering, vine-covered stones, fingers that danced upon the piano with quiet grace; each keystroke a summons to the sonorous spirits of Joy, of Melancholy, of Longing. Shadows played upon her features as she navigated the verdure veiled labyrinth, her thoughts and whispers shared only with the sighing wind, all under the watchful, enigmatic gaze of the manor. Each step was a testament, an ode to her conscious resilience in the face of adversities unspokenâ€”the embodiment of a woman, not simply existing, but persistingly thriving amidst a tale spun by life's erratic loom.
author: bronte

text: In the cloistered serenity of Lowood Hall, isolated in a vale of Yorkshire where the mists draped themselves like wedding trains over the moors and a diffident sun blushed on the infrequent occasion of its appearance, there resided our humble protagonist, Miss Eleanor. Far from the society of fine gentlemen and their fluttering ladies with their birdlike talk of silk fashions and French perfumes, Lowood was an institution of earnest education and stern piety; this was the home of well-worn books, not well-heeled boots. Eleanor was no rare beauty but she was made distinct by a pair of eyes the color of storm clouds and a spirit, too, that fluctuated with the tempestuousness of the weather. In the brown, drab hallways and classrooms of Lowood under the watchful eyes of her austere tutors, Eleanor nurtured a silent rebellion in the form of an insatiable curiosity and a fierce conviction in her own truths.
author: bronte

text: In the gloaming of dank Thornfield Manor, the sullen shadows grew elongated and unwelcoming, like specters from tales whispered in hushed tones by the fireside during the tyranny of winter's reign. Outside, the moor spread its vastness into the echo of the somber night, a wild mistress, alive and breathing, sowing her secrets into the heart of those who dared to listen. Within the desolate stone walls, the tapers flickered, casting ghostly versions of renaissance art, mocking in their lack-of-life the vibrancy of a felicity long since taken. Yet, in this eerie spectacle, a sliver of audacious life stirred - a humble governess of obscure origin yet in possession of an unbroken spirit, daring in its fortitude, whispering the language of hope and endurance in the burdened, ancient environs.
author: bronte

text: Time passed unnoticed, making its unheralded journey along the unseen arc of infinity, and the gentle whispers of change made their approach, appearing on the fringes of the bright morn of spring. Upon the sight of the verdant Moor House, nestled like a beloved child amidst the thriving fabric of nature, the heart of the solitary observer pulsed with a rare kind of enchantment; a singular sentiment of poignant serenity stolen from the bosom of this tranquil wilderness. She, our lonely protagonist, stood awed by the scene â€” an eye trained to discern the tale of every leaf and petal, every sun-dappled stone and whispering wind â€” discovering the symphony of life that composed this celestial hideaway. That residence, inherent with the tentative hopes of bygone eras, simultaneously harboured a certain sorrow sculpted by the ruthless hand of time, each brick and beam narrating stories of quiet passion and despair, served with an intimate familiarity that only solitude can birth. As such, Moor House is no mere edifice of stone and mortar, but rather a living, palpable epistle of humanity's ceaseless dance between joy and sorrow, replete with the rhythm of enduring existence.
author: bronte

text: It was an hour when the world was still, the sun having sung its evening song and withdrawn behind the embroidered curtains of impending twilight. The old manor bore a solitariness so profound, it echoed through its sprawling rooms almost ghostly. Elegance draped in warm, lingering silence; a quietude that only intensifies with each soft rustle of a cambric curtain or lonely flicker of a candle. Dwelling in these hallowed corridors was Constance, a creature of spirit, hope, and unyielding resolve; her soul, a tempest that refused to succumb to the melancholic restraint of her environment. Her heart, despite the overarching desolation of the manor, held a firmament of dreams and sentiments - a spark that burned resolutely in the heartland of the grey, impatient to paint each dreary room with hues of life and warmth from its untamed emotions. With every beat, the heart whispered two simple words into the deep silence, aimed at the damask walls around her - defiance and resilience.
author: bronte

text: Fetters the man, a Goliath whom no David had yet opposed, had fastened himself upon a weak and disorganised community, during a period of great distress and had succeeded by devious ways in making himself its master. And as the colonel stood looking at the picture he was conscious of a faint echo of his boyish indignation and sense of outraged honour. Already Fetters and he had clashed upon the subject of the cotton mill, and Fetters had retired from the field. If it were written that they should meet in a life-and-death struggle for the soul of Clarendon, he would not shirk the conflict. "Laura," he said, when they went away, "I should like to visit the coloured school. Will you come with me?" She hesitated, and he could see with half an eye that her answer was dictated by a fine courage. "Why, certainly, I will go.
author: chesnutt

text: Having looked the work over and given certain directions, he glanced at his watch, and finding it near nine, set out for the justice's office in time to reach it by the appointed hour. Squire Reddick was at his desk, upon which his feet rested, while he read a newspaper. He looked up with an air of surprise as the colonel entered. "Why, good mornin', Colonel French," he said genially. "I kind of expected you a while ago; the clerk said you might be around. But you didn' come, so I supposed you'd changed yo' mind." "The clerk said that you would be here at nine," replied the colonel; "it is only just nine." "Did he? Well, now, that's too bad! I do generally git around about nine, but I was earlier this mornin' and as everybody was here, we started in a little sooner than usual.
author: chesnutt

text: To have married her was to have committed the unpardonable social sin. Such a scandal Mrs. Carteret could not have endured. Should she seek to make restitution, it would necessarily involve the disclosure of at least some of the facts. Had she not destroyed the will, she might have compromised with her conscience by producing it and acting upon its terms, which had been so stated as not to disclose the marriage. This was now rendered impossible by her own impulsive act; she could not mention the will at all, without admitting that she had destroyed it. Mrs. Carteret found herself in what might be called, vulgarly, a moral "pocket." She could, of course, remain silent. Mrs. Carteret was a good woman, according to her lights, with a cultivated conscience, to which she had always looked as her mentor and infallible guide.
author: chesnutt

text: Left alone in his questionable glory, Miller buried himself again in his newspaper, from which he did not look up until the engine stopped at a tank station to take water. As the train came to a standstill, a huge negro, covered thickly with dust, crawled off one of the rear trucks unobserved, and ran round the rear end of the car to a watering-trough by a neighboring well. Moved either by extreme thirst or by the fear that his time might be too short to permit him to draw a bucket of water, he threw himself down by the trough, drank long and deep, and plunging his head into the water, shook himself like a wet dog, and crept furtively back to his dangerous perch. Miller, who had seen this man from the car window, had noticed a very singular thing.
author: chesnutt

text: "I suppose," he said, "that you were looking for a servant, or on some mission of kindness and good will." Miss Laura was silent for a moment and he could feel her hand tremble on the arm he offered her. "No, Henry," she said, "why should I deceive you? I did not go to find a servant, but to serve. I have told you we were poor, but not how poor. I can tell you what I could not say to others, for you have lived away from here, and I know how differently from most of us you look at things. I went to the barber's house to give the barber's daughter music lessons--for money." The colonel laughed contagiously. "You taught her to sing--      _'I dreamt that I dwelt in marble halls? '_"  "Yes, but you must not judge my work too soon," she replied.
author: chesnutt

text: The party broke up at an early hour, since most of the guests were working-people, and the travelers were to make an early start next day. About nine in the morning, Wain drove round to Mis' Molly's. Rena's trunk was strapped behind the buggy, and she set out, in the company of Wain, for her new field of labor. The school term was only two months in length, and she did not expect to return until its expiration. Just before taking her seat in the buggy, Rena felt a sudden sinking of the heart. "Oh, mother," she whispered, as they stood wrapped in a close embrace, "I'm afraid to leave you. I left you once, and it turned out so miserably." "It'll turn out better this time, honey," replied her mother soothingly. "Good-by, child. Take care of yo'self an' yo'r money, and write to yo'r mammy."
author: chesnutt

text: When the train conductor made his round after leaving the station, he paused at the seat occupied by the two doctors, glanced interrogatively at Miller, and then spoke to Dr. Burns, who sat in the end of the seat nearest the aisle. "This man is with you?" he asked, indicating Miller with a slight side movement of his head, and a keen glance in his direction. "Certainly," replied Dr. Burns curtly, and with some surprise. "Don't you see that he is?" The conductor passed on. Miller paid no apparent attention to this little interlude, though no syllable had escaped him. He resumed the conversation where it had been broken off, but nevertheless followed with his eyes the conductor, who stopped at a seat near the forward end of the car, and engaged in conversation with a man whom Miller had not hitherto noticed.
author: chesnutt

text: I have already come near losing my place because of not enforcing it, and I can take no more such chances, since I have a family to support." "And my friend has his rights to maintain," returned Dr. Burns with determination. "There is a vital principle at stake in the matter." "Really, sir," argued the conductor, who was a man of peace and not fond of controversy, "there's no use talking--he absolutely cannot ride in this car." "How can you prevent it?" asked Dr. Burns, lapsing into the argumentative stage. "The law gives me the right to remove him by force. I can call on the train crew to assist me, or on the other passengers. If I should choose to put him off the train entirely, in the middle of a swamp, he would have no redress--the law so provides.
author: chesnutt

text: His life in New York, and in the Clarendon of the present--these were mere transitory embodiments; he lived in the Clarendon yet to be, a Clarendon rescued from Fetters, purified, rehabilitated; and no compassionate angel warned him how tenacious of life that which Fetters stood for might be--that survival of the spirit of slavery, under which the land still groaned and travailed--the growth of generations, which it would take more than one generation to destroy. In describing to Judge Bullard his visit to the cotton mill, the colonel was not sparing of his indignation. "The men," he declared with emphasis, "who are responsible for that sort of thing, are enemies of mankind. I've been in business for twenty years, but I have never sought to make money by trading on the souls and bodies of women and children.
author: chesnutt

text: A party of Northern visitors had been staying for several days at the St. James Hotel. The gentlemen of the party were concerned in a projected cotton mill, while the ladies were much interested in the study of social conditions, and especially in the negro problem. As soon as their desire for information became known, they were taken courteously under the wing of prominent citizens and their wives, who gave them, at elaborate luncheons, the Southern white man's views of the negro, sighing sentimentally over the disappearance of the good old negro of before the war, and gravely deploring the degeneracy of his descendants. They enlarged upon the amount of money the Southern whites had spent for the education of the negro, and shook their heads over the inadequate results accruing from this unexampled generosity.
author: chesnutt

text: He drew the drawer entirely out, and slipped his hand into the cavity. At the back of it he felt the corner of a piece of paper projecting upward from below. The paper had evidently slipped off the top of the others and fallen into a crevice, due to the shrinkage of the wood or some defect of construction. The opening for the drawer was so shallow that though he could feel the end of the paper, he was unable to get such a grasp of it as would permit him to secure it easily. But it was imperative that he have the paper; and since it bore already several signatures obtained with some difficulty, he did not wish to run the risk of tearing it. He examined the compartment below to see if perchance the paper could be reached from there, but found that it could not.
author: chesnutt

text: Since her partial confinement to the house, she had gone, when her health and the weather would permit, to see the child, and at other times had insisted that it be sent to her in charge of the nurse at least every other day. Mrs. Ochiltree's faculties had shared insensibly in the decline of her health. This weakness manifested itself by fits of absent-mindedness, in which she would seemingly lose connection with the present, and live over again, in imagination, the earlier years of her life. She had buried two husbands, had tried in vain to secure a third, and had never borne any children.
author: chesnutt

text: When she saw that he was dead, by a strange revulsion of feeling the wall of outraged pride and hatred and revenge, built upon one brutal and bitterly repented mistake, and labouriously maintained for half a lifetime in her woman's heart that even slavery could not crush, crumbled and fell and let pass over it in one great and final flood the pent-up passions of the past. Bursting into tears--strange tears from eyes that had long forgot to weep--old Viney threw herself down upon her knees by the bedside, and seizing old Malcolm's emaciated hand in both her own, covered it with kisses, fervent kisses, the ghosts of the passionate kisses of their distant youth.
author: chesnutt

text: Old Peter's fine is twenty dollars, and the costs fo' dollars and a half. The prisoner's time is sold to whoever pays his fine and allows him the shortest time to work it out. When his time's up, he goes free." "And what has old Peter done to deserve a fine of twenty dollars--more money than he perhaps has ever had at any one time?" "'Deed, it is, Mars Henry, 'deed it is!" exclaimed Peter, fervently. "Peter has not been able," replied the magistrate, "to show this co't that he has reg'lar employment, or means of suppo't, and he was therefore tried and convicted yesterday evenin' of vagrancy, under our State law. The fine is intended to discourage laziness and to promote industry. Do you want to bid, suh? I'm offered two yeahs, gentlemen, for old Peter French? Does anybody wish to make it less?"
author: chesnutt

text: _Eight_   When the colonel set out next morning for a walk down the main street, he had just breakfasted on boiled brook trout, fresh laid eggs, hot muffins and coffee, and was feeling at peace with all mankind. He was alone, having left Phil in charge of the hotel housekeeper. He had gone only a short distance when he reached a door around which several men were lounging, and from which came the sound of voices and loud laughter. Stopping, he looked with some curiosity into the door, over which there was a faded sign to indicate that it was the office of a Justice of the Peace--a pleasing collocation of words, to those who could divorce it from any technical significance--Justice, Peace--the seed and the flower of civilisation.
author: chesnutt

text: "I am looking for my wife and child," returned Miller in desperation. "They are somewhere in this town,--I don't know where,--and I must find them." Ellis had been horror-stricken by the tragedy of the afternoon, the wholly superfluous slaughter of a harmless people, whom a show of force would have been quite sufficient to overawe. Elaborate explanations were afterwards given for these murders, which were said, perhaps truthfully, not to have been premeditated, and many regrets were expressed. The young man had been surprised, quite as much as the negroes themselves, at the ferocity displayed. His own thoughts and feelings were attuned to anything but slaughter. Only that morning he had received a perfumed note, calling his attention to what the writer described as a very noble deed of his, and requesting him to call that evening and receive the writer's thanks.
author: chesnutt

text: As they approached this structure, which was sufficiently forbidding in appearance to depress the most lighthearted, the strumming of a banjo became audible, accompanying a mellow Negro voice which was singing, to a very ragged ragtime air, words of which the burden was something like this:      _"W'at's de use er my wo'kin' so hahd? I got a' 'oman in de white man's yahd. W'en she cook chicken, she save me a wing;       W'en dey 'low I'm wo'kin', I ain' doin' a thing! "_  The grating of the key in the rusty lock interrupted the song. The constable thrust his prisoner into the dimly lighted interior, and locked the door. "Keep over to the right," he said curtly, "that's the niggers' side." "But, Mistah Haines," asked Peter, excitedly, "is I got to stay here all night? I ain' done nuthin'."
author: chesnutt

text: It was but the work of a moment for Kirby to loosen his partner's collar, reach into the recesses of a certain drawer in the big desk, draw out a flask of brandy, and pour a small quantity of the burning liquid down the unconscious man's throat. A push on one of the electric buttons summoned a clerk, with whose aid Mr. French was lifted to a leather-covered couch that stood against the wall. Almost at once the effect of the stimulant was apparent, and he opened his eyes. "I suspect," he said, with a feeble attempt at a smile, "that I must have fainted--like a woman--perfectly ridiculous." "Perfectly natural," replied his partner. "You have scarcely slept for two weeks--between the business and Phil--and you've reached the end of your string.
author: chesnutt

text: He could do nothing now to show the child his love or Peter his gratitude, and the old man had neither wife nor child in whom the colonel's bounty might find an object. But he would do what he could. He would lay his child's body in the old family lot in the cemetery, among the bones of his ancestors, and there too, close at hand, old Peter should have honourable sepulture. It was his due, and would be the fulfilment of little Phil's last request. The child was laid out in the parlour, amid a mass of flowers. Miss Laura, for love of him and of the colonel, with her own hands prepared his little body for the last sleep. The undertaker, who hovered around, wished, with a conventional sense of fitness, to remove old Peter's body to a back room. But the colonel said no.
author: chesnutt

text: Again she made an inarticulate response, which he nevertheless seemed to comprehend, for, brightening up immediately, he turned from her, came down the steps with tremulous haste, muttering to himself meanwhile, seized a spade that stood leaning against the steps, passed by the carriage without a glance, and began digging furiously at one side of the yard. The old woman watched him for a while, with a self-absorption that was entirely oblivious of the visitors, and then entered the house. The colonel had been completely absorbed in this curious drama. There was an air of weirdness and unreality about it all. Old Peter was as silent as if he had been turned into stone. Something in the atmosphere conduced to somnolence, for even the horses stood still, with no signs of restlessness. The colonel was the first to break the spell. "What's the matter with them, Peter? Do you know?"
author: chesnutt

text: To the good points of Graciella, could be added an untroubled conscience, at least up to that period when Colonel French dawned upon her horizon, and for some time thereafter. If she had put herself foremost in all her thoughts, it had been the unconscious egotism of youth, with no definite purpose of self-seeking. The things for which she wished most were associated with distant places, and her longing for them had never taken the form of envy of those around her. Indeed envy is scarcely a vice of youth; it is a weed that flourishes best after the flower of hope has begun to wither.
author: chesnutt

text: The negroes, going about, had noted, with uneasy curiosity, that the stores and places of business, many of which closed at noon, were unduly late in opening for the afternoon, though no one suspected the reason for the delay; but at three o'clock every passing colored man was ordered, by the first white man he met, to throw up his hands. If he complied, he was searched, more or less roughly, for firearms, and then warned to get off the street. When he met another group of white men the scene was repeated. The man thus summarily held up seldom encountered more than two groups before disappearing across lots to his own home or some convenient hiding-place.
author: chesnutt

text: It was much as though one, having acquired the vernacular of his native country, had lived in a foreign land long enough to lose the language of his childhood without acquiring fully that of his adopted country. Miss Rowena Warwick could never again become quite the Rena Walden who had left the house behind the cedars no more than a year and a half before. Upon this very difference were based her noble aspirations for usefulness,--one must stoop in order that one may lift others. Any other young woman present would have been importuned beyond her powers of resistance. Rena's reserve was respected. When supper was announced, somewhat early in the evening, the dancers found seats in the hall or on the front piazza. Aunt Zilphy, assisted by Mis' Molly and Mary B., passed around the refreshments, which consisted of fried chicken, buttered biscuits, pound-cake, and eggnog.
author: chesnutt

text: The clerk 'll fix it for you. Ransom, the head waiter, will be floor manager." Delamere was struck with a brilliant idea. The more he considered it, the brighter it seemed. Another cocktail imparted additional brilliancy to the conception. He had been trying, after a feeble fashion, to keep his promise to Clara, and was really suffering from lack of excitement. He left the bar-room, found the head waiter, held with him a short conversation, and left in his intelligent and itching palm a piece of money. The cakewalk was a great success. The most brilliant performer was a late arrival, who made his appearance just as the performance was about to commence. The newcomer was dressed strikingly, the conspicuous features of his attire being a long blue coat with brass buttons and a pair of plaid trousers.
author: chesnutt

text: Relying upon his own powers, and upon a woman's weakness and aversion to scandal, from which not even the purest may always escape unscathed, and convinced by her former silence that he had nothing serious to fear, Wain made it a point to be present at every public place where she might be. He assumed, in conversation with her which she could not avoid, and stated to others, that she had left his house because of a previous promise to divide the time of her stay between Elder Johnson's house and his own. He volunteered to teach a class in the Sunday-school which Rena conducted at the colored Methodist church, and when she remained to service, occupied a seat conspicuously near her own.
author: chesnutt

text: Why should he marry you? He did not need to! You are merely lying,--you are not even self-deceived. If he had really married you, you would have made it known long ago. That you did not is proof that your story is false.' "She was hit so hard that she trembled and sank into a chair. But I had no mercy--she had saved your father from _me_--'dear Julia,' indeed! "'Stand up,' I ordered. 'Do not dare to sit down in my presence. I have you on the hip, my lady, and will teach you your place.' "She struggled to her feet, and stood supporting herself with one hand on the chair. I could have killed her, Olivia! She had been my father's slave; if it had been before the war, I would have had her whipped to death. "'You are a thief,' I said, 'and of that there _are_ proofs.
author: chesnutt

text: "Colonel French is an enemy of his race," he declared to his sympathetic following. "He hires niggers when white men are idle; and pays them more than white men who work are earning. And now he is burying them with white people." When the group around the grave began to disperse, the little knot of disgruntled spectators moved sullenly away. In the evening they might have been seen, most of them, around Clay Jackson's barroom. Turner, the foreman at Fetters's convict farm, was in town that evening, and Jackson's was his favourite haunt. For some reason Turner was more sociable than usual, and liquor flowed freely, at his expense. There was a great deal of intemperate talk, concerning the Negro in jail for shooting Haines and young Fetters, and concerning Colonel French as the protector of Negroes and the enemy of white men.
author: chesnutt

text: She had never had any faith in the mythical gold of old Ralph Dudley. The people of an earlier generation--her Aunt Laura perhaps--may once have believed in it, but they had long since ceased to do more than smile pityingly and shake their heads at the mention of old Malcolm's delusion. But there was in it the element of romance. Strange things had happened, and why might they not happen again? And if they should happen, why not to Ben, dear old, shiftless Ben! She moved a porch pillow close beside him, and, as they bent their heads over the paper her hair mingled with his, and soon her hand rested, unconsciously, upon his shoulder. "It was a voice from the grave," said Ben, "for my great-uncle Ralph was dead when the letter reached Uncle Malcolm.
author: chesnutt

text: This primitive oven was heaped with small oysters in the shell, taken from the neighboring sound, and hauled up to the hotel by a negro whose pony cart stood near by. A wet coffee-sack of burlaps was spread over the oysters, which, when steamed sufficiently, were opened by a colored man and served gratis to all who cared for them. Ellis secured a couple of plates of oysters, which he brought to Mrs. Carteret and Clara; they were small, but finely flavored. Meanwhile Delamere, who possessed a remarkable faculty of recuperation from the effects of drink, had waked from his sleep, and remembering his engagement, had exerted himself to overcome the ravages of the afternoon's debauch. A dash of cold water braced him up somewhat. A bottle of seltzer and a big cup of strong coffee still further strengthened his nerves.
author: chesnutt

text: Fetters's friends and hirelings were openly hostile to young Dudley, and Haines had been heard to say, in his cups, at Clay Jackson's saloon, that when young Dudley was tried and convicted and sent to the penitentiary, he would be hired out to Fetters, who had the country contract, and that he, Haines, would be delighted to have Dudley in his gang. The feeling against Dudley grew from day to day, and threats and bets were openly made that he would not live to be tried. There was no direct proof against him, but the moral and circumstantial evidence was quite sufficient to convict him in the eyes of Fetter's friends and supporters.
author: chesnutt

text: He finally left the matter of finding Fetters to Caxton, who ascertained that Fetters would be in attendance at court during a certain week, at Carthage, the county seat of the adjoining county, where the colonel had been once before to inspect a cotton mill. Thither the colonel went on the day of the opening of court. His train reached town toward noon and he went over to the hotel. He wondered if he would find the proprietor sitting where he had found him some weeks before. But the buggy was gone from before the piazza, and there was a new face behind the desk. The colonel registered, left word that he would be in to dinner, and then went over to the court house, which lay behind the trees across the square.
author: chesnutt

text: Steps led up from the street, but one might step from the buggy to the floor of the piazza, which was without a railing. The colonel mounted the steps and passed through the door into a small room, which he took for the hotel office, since there were chairs standing against the walls, and at one side a table on which a register lay open. The only person in the room, beside himself, was a young man seated near the door, with his feet elevated to the back of another chair, reading a newspaper from which he did not look up. The colonel, who wished to make some inquiries and to register for the dinner which he might return to take, looked around him for the clerk, or some one in authority, but no one was visible.
author: chesnutt

text: Personally, I shall never be able to think of you as other than a white man, as you may gather from the tone of this letter; and while I cannot marry your sister, I wish her every happiness, and remain,               Yours very truly,                     GEORGE TRYON. Warwick could not know that this formal epistle was the last of a dozen that Tryon had written and destroyed during the week since the meeting in Patesville,--hot, blistering letters, cold, cutting letters, scornful, crushing letters. Though none of them was sent, except this last, they had furnished a safety-valve for his emotions, and had left him in a state of mind that permitted him to write the foregoing.
author: chesnutt

text: These pitiful attempts to change their physical characteristics were an acknowledgment, on their own part, that the negro was doomed, and that the white man was to inherit the earth and hold all other races under his heel. For, as the months had passed, Carteret's thoughts, centring more and more upon the negro, had led him farther and farther, until now he was firmly convinced that there was no permanent place for the negro in the United States, if indeed anywhere in the world, except under the ground. More pathetic even than Jerry's efforts to escape from the universal doom of his race was his ignorance that even if he could, by some strange alchemy, bleach his skin and straighten his hair, there would still remain, underneath it all, only the unbleached darky,--the ass in the lion's skin.
author: chesnutt

text: _Twenty-seven_   His first step was to have Caxton look up and abstract for him the criminal laws of the State. They were bad enough, in all conscience. Men could be tried without jury and condemned to infamous punishments, involving stripes and chains, for misdemeanours which in more enlightened States were punished with a small fine or brief detention. There were, for instance, no degrees of larceny, and the heaviest punishment might be inflicted, at the discretion of the judge, for the least offense. The vagrancy law, of which the colonel had had some experience, was an open bid for injustice and "graft" and clearly designed to profit the strong at the expense of the weak. The crop-lien laws were little more than the instruments of organised robbery. To these laws the colonel called the attention of some of his neighbours with whom he was on terms of intimacy.
author: chesnutt

text: But as the turpentine industry had moved southward, leaving a trail of devastated forests in its rear, the city had fallen to a poor fifth or sixth place in this trade, relying now almost entirely upon cotton for its export business. Occasionally our party passed a person, or a group of persons,--mostly negroes approximating the pure type, for those of lighter color grew noticeably scarcer as the town was left behind. Now and then one of these would salute the party respectfully, while others glanced at them indifferently or turned away. There would have seemed, to a stranger, a lack, of spontaneous friendliness between the people of these two races, as though each felt that it had no part or lot in the other's life. At one point the carriage drew near a party of colored folks who were laughing and jesting among themselves with great glee.
author: chesnutt

text: That he did not keep it shut may be inferred from the fact that within the next half hour he had eaten and drunk fifty cents' worth of candy, ginger-pop, and other available delicacies that appealed to the youthful palate. Having nothing more to spend, and the high prices prevailing for some time after the war having left him capable of locomotion, Plato was promptly on hand at the appointed time and place. Tryon placed a letter in Plato's hand, still sticky with molasses candy,--he had inclosed it in a second cover by way of protection. "Give that letter," he said, "to your teacher; don't say a word about it to a living soul; bring me an answer, and give it into my own hand, and you shall have another half dollar." Tryon was quite aware that by a surreptitious correspondence he ran some risk of compromising Rena.
author: chesnutt

text: "All right, Mistuh Tom, you shill have de money; but I wants ter tell you, suh, dat in all de yeahs I has wo'ked fer yo' gran'daddy, he has never called me a 'darky' ter my face, suh. Co'se I knows dere's w'ite folks an' black folks,--but dere's manners, suh, dere's manners, an' gent'emen oughter be de ones ter use 'em, suh, ef dey ain't ter be fergot enti'ely!" "There, there, Sandy," returned Tom in a conciliatory tone, "I beg your pardon! I've been associating with some Northern white folks at the hotel, and picked up the word from them. You're a high-toned colored gentleman, Sandy,--the finest one on the footstool." Still muttering to himself, Sandy retired to his own room, which was in the house, so that he might be always near his master.
author: chesnutt

text: In the mail-bag under the driver's seat were Rena's two letters; they had been delivered at the town in the morning, and immediately remailed to Clarence, in accordance with orders left at the post-office the evening before. Tryon and Warwick drove leisurely homeward through the pines, all unconscious of the fateful squares of white paper moving along the road a few miles before them, which a mother's yearning and a daughter's love had thrown, like the apple of discord, into the narrow circle of their happiness. They reached Clarence at four o'clock. Warwick got down from the buggy at his office. Tryon drove on to his hotel, to make a hasty toilet before visiting his sweetheart. Warwick glanced at his mail, tore open the envelope addressed in his sister's handwriting, and read the contents with something like dismay.
author: chesnutt

text: Free colored people in North Carolina exercised the right of suffrage as late as 1835, and some of them, in spite of galling restrictions, attained to a considerable degree of prosperity, and dreamed of a still brighter future, when the growing tyranny of the slave power crushed their hopes and crowded the free people back upon the black mass just beneath them. Mis' Molly's father had been at one time a man of some means. In an evil hour, with an overweening confidence in his fellow men, he indorsed a note for a white man who, in a moment of financial hardship, clapped his colored neighbor on the back and called him brother. Not poverty, but wealth, is the most potent leveler. In due time the indorser was called upon to meet the maturing obligation.
author: chesnutt

text: The enlightened few had scarcely known of their existence, and quite agreed that the laws were harsh and ought to be changed. But when the colonel, pursuing his inquiry, undertook to investigate the operation of these laws, he found an appalling condition. The statutes were mild and beneficent compared with the results obtained under cover of them. Caxton spent several weeks about the State looking up the criminal records, and following up the sentences inflicted, working not merely for his fee, but sharing the colonel's indignation at the state of things unearthed. Convict labour was contracted out to private parties, with little or no effective State supervision, on terms which, though exceedingly profitable to the State, were disastrous to free competitive labour. More than one lawmaker besides Fetters was numbered among these contractors.
author: chesnutt

text: We have plenty of other cases against Fetters." Within a week, Johnson, with the connivance of a bribed guard, a poor-white man from Clarendon, had escaped from Fetters and seemingly vanished from Beaver County. Fetters's lieutenants were active in their search for him, but sought in vain. _Twenty-eight_   Ben Dudley awoke the morning after the assembly ball, with a violent headache and a sense of extreme depression, which was not relieved by the sight of his reflection in the looking-glass of the bureau in the hotel bedroom where he found himself. One of his eyes was bloodshot, and surrounded by a wide area of discolouration, and he was conscious of several painful contusions on other portions of his body. His clothing was badly disordered and stained with blood; and, all in all, he was scarcely in a condition to appear in public.
author: chesnutt

text: If the worst happened, she must know, of course; if not, then, being a woman whom they both liked--she would be spared needless anxiety. How closely they had skirted the edge of disaster she did not learn until afterward; indeed, Kirby himself had scarcely appreciated the true situation, and even the senior partner, since he had not been present at the meeting of the trust managers, could not know what had been in their minds. But Kirby's voice gave no hint of these reflections. He laughed a cheerful laugh. "If the world only knew," he rejoined, "it would cease to worry about the pains of poverty, and weep for the woes of wealth." "Indeed it would!" she replied, with a seriousness which seemed almost sincere. "Is Mr. French there? I wish to thank him, too." "No, he has just gone home." "At this hour?"
author: chesnutt

text: An' de Lawd is gwine bless you, suh, you an' my sweet young lady, fuh bein' good to po' folks w'at can't do nuthin' to he'p deyse'ves out er trouble," said Catharine backing out with her apron to her eyes. *       *       *       *       *  On leaving Miss Laura, the colonel went round to the office of Squire Reddick, the justice of the peace, to inquire into the matter of Bud Johnson. The justice was out of town, his clerk said, but would be in his office at nine in the morning, at which time the colonel could speak to him about Johnson's fine. The next morning was bright and clear, and cool enough to be bracing. The colonel, alive with pleasant thoughts, rose early and after a cold bath, and a leisurely breakfast, walked over to the mill site, where the men were already at work.
author: chesnutt

text: "I certainly hope so," said Miss Laura earnestly. "I am sorry for Ben, but I could not permit a drunken rowdy to come to the house, or let my niece be seen upon the street with him." "It would only be fair," said the colonel, "to give him a chance to explain, when he comes in again. I rather like Ben. He has some fine mechanical ideas, and the making of a man in him, unless I am mistaken. I have been hoping to find a place for him in the new cotton mill, when it is ready to run." They were still speaking of Ben, when there was an irresolute knock at the rear door of the parlour, in which they were seated. "Miss Laura, O Miss Laura," came a muffled voice. "Kin I speak to you a minute. It's mighty pertickler, Miss Laura, fo' God it is!"
author: chesnutt

text: His aristocratic gorge rose at the presumption of this son of an overseer and ex-driver of convicts. McBane was good enough to win money from, or even to lose money to, but not good enough to be recognized as a social equal. He would instinctively have blackballed McBane had he been proposed by some one else; with what grace could he put himself forward as the sponsor for this impossible social aspirant? Moreover, it was clearly a vulgar, cold-blooded attempt on McBane's part to use his power over him for a personal advantage. "Well, now, Captain McBane," returned Delamere diplomatically, "I've never put any one up yet, and it's not regarded as good form for so young a member as myself to propose candidates. I'd much rather you'd ask some older man." "Oh, well," replied McBane, "just as you say, only I thought you had cut your eye teeth."
author: chesnutt

text: "Ef you ever wanter come home, an' can't git back no other way, jes' let ME know, an' I'll take my mule an' my kyart an' fetch you back, ef it's from de een' er de worl'." "Thank you, Frank, I believe you would," said the girl kindly. "You're a true friend, Frank, and I'll not forget you while I'm gone." The idea of her beautiful daughter riding home from the end of the world with Frank, in a cart, behind a one-eyed mule, struck Mis' Molly as the height of the ridiculous--she was in a state of excitement where tears or laughter would have come with equal ease--and she turned away to hide her merriment. Her daughter was going to live in a fine house, and marry a rich man, and ride in her carriage.
author: chesnutt

text: It denied that most lynchings were for the offense most generally charged as their justification, and declared that, even of those seemingly traced to this cause, many were not for crimes at all, but for voluntary acts which might naturally be expected to follow from the miscegenation laws by which it was sought, in all the Southern States, to destroy liberty of contract, and, for the purpose of maintaining a fanciful purity of race, to make crimes of marriages to which neither nature nor religion nor the laws of other states interposed any insurmountable barrier.
author: chesnutt

text: "Put me down hyuh at de foot er de lot, little Mars' Phil, unner dis ellum tree." "Oh, papa," exclaimed Phil, demanding the colonel's attention, "Uncle Peter and I have arranged everything. You know Uncle Peter is to stay with me as long as I live, and when he dies, he is to be buried here at the foot of the lot, under the elm tree, where he'll be near me all the time, and near the folks that he knows and that know him." "All right, Phil. You see to it; you'll live longer." "But, papa, if I should die first, and then Uncle Peter, and you last of all, you'll put Uncle Peter near me, won't you, papa?" "Why, bless your little heart, Phil, of course your daddy will do whatever you want, if he's here to do it.
author: chesnutt

text: He had said nothing about this discovery, but had merely noted it as something which at some future time might prove useful. The captain had not suffered by Delamere's deviation from the straight line of honor, for while Tom was as clever with the cards as might be expected of a young man who had devoted most of his leisure for several years to handling them, McBane was past master in their manipulation. During a stormy career he had touched more or less pitch, and had escaped few sorts of defilement.
