text: In the large kitchen, where I dimly saw bacon and ropes of onions hanging from the beams, the watchers were clustered together, in various attitudes, about a table, purposely moved away from the great chimney, and brought near the door. A pretty girl, who had her ears stopped with her apron, and her eyes upon the door, screamed when I appeared, supposing me to be a spirit; but the others had more presence of mind, and were glad of an addition to their company. One man, referring to the topic they had been discussing, asked me whether I thought the souls of the collier-crews who had gone down, were out in the storm? I remained there, I dare say, two hours. Once, I opened the yard-gate, and looked into the empty street.

text: â€œTell me all about Walter first; let me understand this history all through.â€  Florence related it, and everything belonging to it, even down to the friendship of Mr Toots, of whom she could hardly speak in her distress without a tearful smile, although she was deeply grateful to him. When she had concluded her account, to the whole of which Edith, holding her hand, listened with close attention, and when a silence had succeeded, Edith said:  â€œWhat is it that you know I have seen, Florence?â€  â€œThat I am not,â€ said Florence, with the same mute appeal, and the same quick concealment of her face as before, â€œthat I am not a favourite child, Mama. I never have been. I have never known how to be. I have missed the way, and had no one to show it to me.

text: â€˜Supposing,â€™ he would say, stating the case with his key on the professional gentlemanâ€™s waistcoat; â€˜supposing a man wanted to leave his property to a young female, and wanted to tie it up so that nobody else should ever be able to make a grab at it; how would you tie up that property?â€™  â€˜Settle it strictly on herself,â€™ the professional gentleman would complacently answer. â€˜But look here,â€™ quoth the turnkey. â€˜Supposing she had, say a brother, say a father, say a husband, who would be likely to make a grab at that property when she came into it--how about that?â€™  â€˜It would be settled on herself, and they would have no more legal claim on it than you,â€™ would be the professional answer. â€˜Stop a bit,â€™ said the turnkey. â€˜Supposing she was tender-hearted, and they came over her.

text: At those times, when he is not visited by Mr. Guppy or by a small light in his likeness quenched in a dark hat, he comes out of his dull roomâ€”where he has inherited the deal wilderness of desk bespattered with a rain of inkâ€”and talks to Krook or is â€œvery free,â€ as they call it in the court, commendingly, with any one disposed for conversation.

text: Oh!â€ for I was going to thank him, â€œI tell you at once, I am paid for my services, or I shouldnâ€™t render them. It is considered that you must be better educated, in accordance with your altered position, and that you will be alive to the importance and necessity of at once entering on that advantage.â€  I said I had always longed for it. â€œNever mind what you have always longed for, Mr. Pip,â€ he retorted; â€œkeep to the record. If you long for it now, thatâ€™s enough. Am I answered that you are ready to be placed at once under some proper tutor? Is that it?â€  I stammered yes, that was it. â€œGood. text: I remember dreaming night after night, of being with my mother as she used to be, or of going to a party at Mr. Peggottyâ€™s, or of travelling outside the stage-coach, or of dining again with my unfortunate friend the waiter, and in all these circumstances making people scream and stare, by the unhappy disclosure that I had nothing on but my little night-shirt, and that placard. In the monotony of my life, and in my constant apprehension of the re-opening of the school, it was such an insupportable affliction! I had long tasks every day to do with Mr. Mell; but I did them, there being no Mr. and Miss Murdstone here, and got through them without disgrace. Before, and after them, I walked about--supervised, as I have mentioned, by the man with the wooden leg.

text: He had, therefore, no self-disrespect to avenge; no long-tightened springs to release with a quick recoil. He worked early and late to unravel whatever was complicated or difficult in the records of the transactions of the House; was always in attendance to explain whatever required explanation; sat in his old room sometimes very late at night, studying points by his mastery of which he could spare Mr Dombey the pain of being personally referred to; and then would go home to Islington, and calm his mind by producing the most dismal and forlorn sounds out of his violoncello before going to bed.

text: I had not the least belief, in the outset of this story, that the unknown was anything but a delusion of Mr. Dickâ€™s, and one of the line of that ill-fated Prince who occasioned him so much difficulty; but after some reflection I began to entertain the question whether an attempt, or threat of an attempt, might have been twice made to take poor Mr. Dick himself from under my auntâ€™s protection, and whether my aunt, the strength of whose kind feeling towards him I knew from herself, might have been induced to pay a price for his peace and quiet. As I was already much attached to Mr. Dick, and very solicitous for his welfare, my fears favoured this supposition; and for a long time his Wednesday hardly ever came round, without my entertaining a misgiving that he would not be on the coach-box as usual.

text: said the captain, administering several pokes to Mr. Pickwick's body with the thick stick. 'What's your name?' 'Cold punch,' murmured Mr. Pickwick, as he sank to sleep again. 'What?' demanded Captain Boldwig. No reply. 'What did he say his name was?' asked the captain. 'Punch, I think, sir,' replied Wilkins. 'That's his impudence--that's his confounded impudence,' said Captain Boldwig. 'He's only feigning to be asleep now,' said the captain, in a high passion. 'He's drunk; he's a drunken plebeian. Wheel him away, Wilkins, wheel him away directly.' Where shall I wheel him to, sir?' inquired Wilkins, with great timidity. 'Wheel him to the devil,' replied Captain Boldwig. 'Very well, sir,' said Wilkins. 'Stay,' said the captain. Wilkins stopped accordingly. 'Wheel him,' said the captain--'wheel him to the pound; and let us see whether he calls himself Punch when he comes to himself. He shall not bully me--he shall not bully me. Wheel him away.'

text: The licence of look and touch,â€ she said, with flashing eyes, â€œhave I submitted to it, in half the places of resort upon the map of England? Do not tell me that I had, tonight of all nights in my life!â€  â€œYou might have been well married,â€ said her mother, â€œtwenty times at least, Edith, if you had given encouragement enough.â€  â€œNo! text: â€œDare I ask you to explain?â€  â€œI believe that if you were not in disgrace with the Court, and had not been overshadowed by that cloud for years past, a letter de cachet would have sent me to some fortress indefinitely.â€  â€œIt is possible,â€ said the uncle, with great calmness. â€œFor the honour of the family, I could even resolve to incommode you to that extent. text: Clerk after clerk hastened into the square by one or other of the entrances, and looking up at the Hall clock, accelerated or decreased his rate of walking according to the time at which his office hours nominally commenced; the half-past nine o'clock people suddenly becoming very brisk, and the ten o'clock gentlemen falling into a pace of most aristocratic slowness. The clock struck ten, and clerks poured in faster than ever, each one in a greater perspiration than his predecessor. The noise of unlocking and opening doors echoed and re-echoed on every side; heads appeared as if by magic in every window; the porters took up their stations for the day; the slipshod laundresses hurried off; the postman ran from house to house; and the whole legal hive was in a bustle. 'You're early, Mr. Pickwick,' said a voice behind him.

text: Through his way of saying this, and much more to similar purpose, he placed himself on confidential terms with me in an admirable manner; and I may state at once that he was always so zealous and honourable in fulfilling his compact with me, that he made me zealous and honourable in fulfilling mine with him. If he had shown indifference as a master, I have no doubt I should have returned the compliment as a pupil; he gave me no such excuse, and each of us did the other justice. Nor did I ever regard him as having anything ludicrous about himâ€”or anything but what was serious, honest, and goodâ€”in his tutor communication with me.

text: 'Where in the name of the Gunpowder Plot did you pick up this?' said his master. It was given him by a person then waiting at the door, the man replied. text: If you throw away this chance, you will both richly deserve to be hanged, as I sincerely trust you will be. text: There is also a legend of a young gentleman, who, not having before his eyes the fear of the canons of the church for such cases made and provided, conceived a passion for his grandmother. Arthur Gride had enrobed himself in his marriage garments of bottle-green, a full hour before Mrs. Sliderskew, shaking off her more heavy slumbers, knocked at his chamber door; and he had hobbled downstairs in full array and smacked his lips over a scanty taste of his favourite cordial, ere that delicate piece of antiquity enlightened the kitchen with her presence. text: The time agreed upon had not quite come; but Mr Fips was already at the Temple Gate, and expressed his satisfaction at their punctuality. Stopping before a door upon an upper story, which had nothing but a yellow smear of paint where custom would have placed the tenant's name, he began to beat the dust out of one of these keys, very deliberately, upon the great broad handrail of the balustrade. text: 'Yes--for every kind and honest word you uttered, went to my heart. For you, who have borne so much from me--for you, who owe your sufferings and pain to my caprice--for you to be so kind--so noble to me, Joe--'  He could say nothing to her. Not a syllable. There was an odd sort of eloquence in his one arm, which had crept round her waist: but his lips were mute. 'If you had reminded me by a word--only by one short word,' sobbed Dolly, clinging yet closer to him, 'how little I deserved that you should treat me with so much forbearance; if you had exulted only for one moment in your triumph, I could have borne it better.' 'Triumph!' repeated Joe, with a smile which seemed to say, 'I am a pretty figure for that.'

text: 'As to our own share in the precious little mystery,' said Mr Pecksniff, 'we will keep it to ourselves, and talk of it between ourselves, and you shall think it over. You will consent, my love; you will consent, I know. Whatever you may think; you will. I seem to remember to have heard--I really don't know where, or how'--he added, with bewitching frankness, 'that you and Martin junior, when you were children, had a sort of childish fondness for each other. When we are married, you shall have the satisfaction of thinking that it didn't last to ruin him, but passed away to do him good; for we'll see then what we can do to put some trifling help in Martin junior's way. HAVE I any influence with our venerable friend? Well! Perhaps I have. Perhaps I have.'

text: The burning pile, revealing rooms and passages red hot, through gaps made in the crumbling walls; the tributary fires that licked the outer bricks and stones, with their long forked tongues, and ran up to meet the glowing mass within; the shining of the flames upon the villains who looked on and fed them; the roaring of the angry blaze, so bright and high that it seemed in its rapacity to have swallowed up the very smoke; the living flakes the wind bore rapidly away and hurried on with, like a storm of fiery snow; the noiseless breaking of great beams of wood, which fell like feathers on the heap of ashes, and crumbled in the very act to sparks and powder; the lurid tinge that overspread the sky, and the darkness, very deep by contrast, which prevailed around; the exposure to the coarse, common gaze, of every little nook which usages of home had made a sacred place, and the destruction by rude hands of every little household favourite which old associations made a dear and precious thing: all this taking place--not among pitying looks and friendly murmurs of compassion, but brutal shouts and exultations, which seemed to make the very rats who stood by the old house too long, creatures with some claim upon the pity and regard of those its roof had sheltered:--combined to form a scene never to be forgotten by those who saw it and were not actors in the work, so long as life endured.
author: dickens

text: Still, with an unshaken confidence that the English tongue was somehow the mother tongue of the whole world, only the people were too stupid to know it, Mr Meagles harangued innkeepers in the most voluble manner, entered into loud explanations of the most complicated sort, and utterly renounced replies in the native language of the respondents, on the ground that they were â€˜all bosh.â€™ Sometimes interpreters were called in; whom Mr Meagles addressed in such idiomatic terms of speech, as instantly to extinguish and shut up--which made the matter worse. On a balance of the account, however, it may be doubted whether he lost much; for, although he found no property, he found so many debts and various associations of discredit with the proper name, which was the only word he made intelligible, that he was almost everywhere overwhelmed with injurious accusations.

text: Let me tell him, gentlemen, that any gestures of dissent or disapprobation in which he may indulge in this court will not go down with you; that you will know how to value and how to appreciate them; and let me tell him further, as my Lord will tell you, gentlemen, that a counsel, in the discharge of his duty to his client, is neither to be intimidated nor bullied, nor put down; and that any attempt to do either the one or the other, or the first, or the last, will recoil on the head of the attempter, be he plaintiff or be he defendant, be his name Pickwick, or Noakes, or Stoakes, or Stiles, or Brown, or Thompson.' text: There were a thousand pleasant scents diffused around, from young leaves and fresh buds; the cuckoo had been singing all day long, and was but just now hushed; the smell of earth newly-upturned, first breath of hope to the first labourer after his garden withered, was fragrant in the evening breeze. It was a time when most men cherish good resolves, and sorrow for the wasted past; when most men, looking on the shadows as they gather, think of that evening which must close on all, and that to-morrow which has none beyond. 'Precious dull,' said Mr Jonas, looking about. 'It's enough to make a man go melancholy mad.' 'We shall have lights and a fire soon,' observed Mr Pecksniff. text: He only hinted this, and very distantly; knowing that it pained Tom Pinch to have that gentleman disparaged, and thinking it would be as well to leave the new pupil to his own discoveries. text: Finding such clerk on Wemmickâ€™s post that morning, I knew what was going on; but I was not sorry to have Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick together, as Wemmick would then hear for himself that I said nothing to compromise him. Although I had sent Mr. Jaggers a brief account of the accident as soon as I had arrived in town, yet I had to give him all the details now; and the speciality of the occasion caused our talk to be less dry and hard, and less strictly regulated by the rules of evidence, than it had been before. text: With my head full of George Barnwell, I was at first disposed to believe that _I_ must have had some hand in the attack upon my sister, or at all events that as her near relation, popularly known to be under obligations to her, I was a more legitimate object of suspicion than any one else. But when, in the clearer light of next morning, I began to reconsider the matter and to hear it discussed around me on all sides, I took another view of the case, which was more reasonable. Joe had been at the Three Jolly Bargemen, smoking his pipe, from a quarter after eight oâ€™clock to a quarter before ten. text: I could not help feeling, though she mingled her tears with mine, that she had a dreadful luxury in our afflictions. She petted them, as I may say, and made the most of them. No matter, Miss Mills remarked. Hearts confined by cobwebs would burst at last, and then Love was avenged. This was small consolation, but Miss Mills wouldnâ€™t encourage fallacious hopes. text: To the excogitation of this problem, the harmless gentleman had devoted many anxious hours, both in his lodgings over the livery stable-yard, and in the cold gloom, favourable to meditation, of Saint Jamesâ€™s Square. Thus. Twemlow had first known Veneering at his club, where Veneering then knew nobody but the man who made them known to one another, who seemed to be the most intimate friend he had in the world, and whom he had known two days--the bond of union between their souls, the nefarious conduct of the committee respecting the cookery of a fillet of veal, having been accidentally cemented at that date. Immediately upon this, Twemlow received an invitation to dine with Veneering, and dined: the man being of the party. Immediately upon that, Twemlow received an invitation to dine with the man, and dined: Veneering being of the party.
author: dickens

text: Mr. Bumble, who was ashamed or afraid to lag behind, followed: obviously very ill at ease and with scarcely any of that remarkable dignity which was usually his chief characteristic. â€œWhat the devil made you stand lingering there, in the wet?â€ said Monks, turning round, and addressing Bumble, after he had bolted the door behind them. â€œWeâ€”we were only cooling ourselves,â€ stammered Bumble, looking apprehensively about him. â€œCooling yourselves!â€ retorted Monks. â€œNot all the rain that ever fell, or ever will fall, will put as much of hellâ€™s fire out, as a man can carry about with him. You wonâ€™t cool yourself so easily; donâ€™t think it!â€  With this agreeable speech, Monks turned short upon the matron, and bent his gaze upon her, till even she, who was not easily cowed, was fain to withdraw her eyes, and turn them towards the ground.
author: dickens

text: Therefore he availed himself of so favourable a moment for breaking the West Indian intelligence to his friend, as a piece of extraordinary preferment; declaring that for his part he would freely give a hundred thousand pounds (if he had it) for Walterâ€™s gain in the long-run, and that he had no doubt such an investment would yield a handsome premium. Solomon Gills was at first stunned by the communication, which fell upon the little back-parlour like a thunderbolt, and tore up the hearth savagely. But the Captain flashed such golden prospects before his dim sight: hinted so mysteriously at Whittingtonian consequences; laid such emphasis on what Walter had just now told them: and appealed to it so confidently as a corroboration of his predictions, and a great advance towards the realisation of the romantic legend of Lovely Peg: that he bewildered the old man.
author: dickens

text: Is Mr Blandois a friend of yours?â€™  â€˜No--a--hum--an acquaintance,â€™ answered Mr Dorrit. â€˜You have no commission from him, perhaps?â€™  â€˜I? Ha. Certainly not.â€™  The searching look turned gradually to the floor, after taking Mr Flintwinchâ€™s face in its way. Mr Dorrit, discomfited by finding that he was the questioned instead of the questioner, applied himself to the reversal of that unexpected order of things. â€˜I am--ha--a gentleman of property, at present residing in Italy with my family, my servants, and--hum--my rather large establishment.

text: And what thick boots!â€  I had never thought of being ashamed of my hands before; but I began to consider them a very indifferent pair. Her contempt for me was so strong, that it became infectious, and I caught it. She won the game, and I dealt. I misdealt, as was only natural, when I knew she was lying in wait for me to do wrong; and she denounced me for a stupid, clumsy labouring-boy. â€œYou say nothing of her,â€ remarked Miss Havisham to me, as she looked on. â€œShe says many hard things of you, but you say nothing of her. What do you think of her?â€  â€œI donâ€™t like to say,â€ I stammered. â€œTell me in my ear,â€ said Miss Havisham, bending down. â€œI think she is very proud,â€ I replied, in a whisper.

text: That was before I knew you, but I was pretty sure I couldn't be mistaken. He is light and active, I suppose. But those were slight advantages compared with yours. Luck, luck! These hang-dog outcasts have it.' 'He'll need the most he has, when I am well again,' said Sir Mulberry Hawk, 'let him fly where he will.' 'Oh!' returned Ralph quickly, 'he doesn't dream of that.

text: I wondered whether the two swollen faces were of Mr. Jaggersâ€™s family, and, if he were so unfortunate as to have had a pair of such ill-looking relations, why he stuck them on that dusty perch for the blacks and flies to settle on, instead of giving them a place at home. Of course I had no experience of a London summer day, and my spirits may have been oppressed by the hot exhausted air, and by the dust and grit that lay thick on everything. But I sat wondering and waiting in Mr. Jaggersâ€™s close room, until I really could not bear the two casts on the shelf above Mr. Jaggersâ€™s chair, and got up and went out.

text: 'I beg your pardon, sir, for interrupting you,' said Mr. Pickwick; 'but before you proceed to express, and act upon, any opinion you may have formed on the statements which have been made here, I must claim my right to be heard so far as I am personally concerned.' 'Hold your tongue, Sir,' said the magistrate peremptorily. 'I must submit to you, Sir--' said Mr. Pickwick. 'Hold your tongue, sir,' interposed the magistrate, 'or I shall order an officer to remove you.' 'You may order your officers to do whatever you please, Sir,' said Mr. Pickwick; 'and I have no doubt, from the specimen I have had of the subordination preserved amongst them, that whatever you order, they will execute, Sir; but I shall take the liberty, Sir, of claiming my right to be heard, until I am removed by force.' 'Pickvick and principle!' exclaimed Mr. Weller, in a very audible voice. 'Sam, be quiet,' said Mr. Pickwick.
author: dickens

text: Did you marry money?â€™  â€˜You know I didnâ€™t, my dear.â€™  Bella hummed the Dead March in Saul, and said, after all it signified very little! But seeing him look grave and downcast, she took him round the neck and kissed him back to cheerfulness again. â€˜I didnâ€™t mean that last touch, Pa; it was only said in joke. Now mind! You are not to tell of me, and Iâ€™ll not tell of you. And more than that; I promise to have no secrets from you, Pa, and you may make certain that, whatever mercenary things go on, I shall always tell you all about them in strict confidence.â€™  Fain to be satisfied with this concession from the lovely woman, R. W. rang the bell, and paid the bill.
author: dickens

text: There's no harm in thinking of such things.' 'Not in dreams,' returned the Secretary. 'In dreams! No, nor waking either.' --'"Called, and chosen, and faithful,"' said Gashford, taking up Lord George's watch which lay upon a chair, and seeming to read the inscription on the seal, abstractedly. It was the slightest action possible, not obtruded on his notice, and apparently the result of a moment's absence of mind, not worth remark. But as the words were uttered, Lord George, who had been going on impetuously, stopped short, reddened, and was silent. Apparently quite unconscious of this change in his demeanour, the wily Secretary stepped a little apart, under pretence of pulling up the window-blind, and returning when the other had had time to recover, said:  'The holy cause goes bravely on, my lord. I was not idle, even last night.
author: dickens

text: I am very sorry!â€™  When she opened her eyes, and saw where she was, and that we were all standing about her, she arose with assistance: turning her head, as she did so, to lay it on the Doctorâ€™s shoulder--or to hide it, I donâ€™t know which. We went into the drawing-room, to leave her with the Doctor and her mother; but she said, it seemed, that she was better than she had been since morning, and that she would rather be brought among us; so they brought her in, looking very white and weak, I thought, and sat her on a sofa. â€˜Annie, my dear,â€™ said her mother, doing something to her dress. â€˜See here! You have lost a bow. Will anybody be so good as find a ribbon; a cherry-coloured ribbon?â€™  It was the one she had worn at her bosom.
author: dickens

text: 'His price,' said the gentleman, rattling the money in his pockets, 'what dost want for him? How much?' 'He's not to be sold,' replied Barnaby, shutting up the basket in a great hurry, and throwing the strap over his shoulder. 'Mother, come away.' 'Thou seest how much of an idiot he is, book-learner,' said the gentleman, looking scornfully at his wife. 'He can make a bargain. What dost want for him, old woman?' 'He is my son's constant companion,' said the widow. 'He is not to be sold, sir, indeed.' 'Not to be sold!' cried the gentleman, growing ten times redder, hoarser, and louder than before. 'Not to be sold!' 'Indeed no,' she answered. 'We have never thought of parting with him, sir, I do assure you.' He was evidently about to make a very passionate retort, when a few murmured words from his wife happening to catch his ear, he turned sharply round, and said, 'Eh? What?'
author: dickens

text: â€˜Havenâ€™t I this moment come?â€™  â€˜Well, all I know is,â€™ replied Miss Sally, â€˜that itâ€™s not to be found, and that it disappeared one day this week, when I left it on the desk.â€™  â€˜Halloa!â€™ thought Richard, â€˜I hope the Marchioness hasnâ€™t been at work here.â€™  â€˜There was a knife too,â€™ said Miss Sally, â€˜of the same pattern. They were given to me by my father, years ago, and are both gone. You havenâ€™t missed anything yourself, have you?â€™  Mr Swiveller involuntarily clapped his hands to the jacket to be quite sure that it WAS a jacket and not a skirted coat; and having satisfied himself of the safety of this, his only moveable in Bevis Marks, made answer in the negative.
author: dickens

text: â€œI beg your pardon, Miss, Iâ€™m sure,â€ said Towlinson, outside the door with the boxes, addressing Florence, â€œbut Mr Toots is in the drawing-room, and sends his compliments, and begs to know how Diogenes and Master is.â€  Quick as thought, Florence glided out and hastened downstairs, where Mr Toots, in the most splendid vestments, was breathing very hard with doubt and agitation on the subject of her coming. â€œOh, how de do, Miss Dombey,â€ said Mr Toots, â€œGod bless my soul!â€  This last ejaculation was occasioned by Mr Tootsâ€™s deep concern at the distress he saw in Florenceâ€™s face; which caused him to stop short in a fit of chuckles, and become an image of despair.
author: dickens

text: Good-night--a--a--God bless you.' The blessing seemed to stick in Mr. Ralph Nickleby's throat, as if it were not used to the thoroughfare, and didn't know the way out. But it got out somehow, though awkwardly enough; and having disposed of it, he shook hands with his two relatives, and abruptly left them. 'What a very strongly marked countenance your uncle has!' said Mrs Nickleby, quite struck with his parting look. 'I don't see the slightest resemblance to his poor brother.' 'Mama!' said Kate reprovingly. 'To think of such a thing!' 'No,' said Mrs. Nickleby, musing. 'There certainly is none. But it's a very honest face.' The worthy matron made this remark with great emphasis and elocution, as if it comprised no small quantity of ingenuity and research; and, in truth, it was not unworthy of being classed among the extraordinary discoveries of the age.
author: dickens

text: I reply, then, they are not identical with those of Mr. Jarndyce.â€  â€œOf course they are not!â€ cries Richard. â€œYou found that out long ago.â€  â€œMr. C.,â€ returns Vholes, â€œI wish to say no more of any third party than is necessary. I wish to leave my good name unsullied, together with any little property of which I may become possessed through industry and perseverance, to my daughters Emma, Jane, and Caroline. I also desire to live in amity with my professional brethren. When Mr. Skimpole did me the honour, sirâ€”I will not say the very high honour, for I never stoop to flatteryâ€”of bringing us together in this room, I mentioned to you that I could offer no opinion or advice as to your interests while those interests were entrusted to another member of the profession.
author: dickens

text: I hope your time is not so precious but that you will allow my Lady and myself to offer you the hospitality of Chesney Wold, for to-night at least.â€  â€œI hope so,â€ adds my Lady. â€œI am much obliged to you, but I have to travel all night in order to reach a distant part of the country punctually at an appointed time in the morning.â€  Therewith the ironmaster takes his departure, Sir Leicester ringing the bell and my Lady rising as he leaves the room. When my Lady goes to her boudoir, she sits down thoughtfully by the fire, and inattentive to the Ghostâ€™s Walk, looks at Rosa, writing in an inner room. Presently my Lady calls her. â€œCome to me, child. Tell me the truth. Are you in love?â€  â€œOh! My Lady!â€  My Lady, looking at the downcast and blushing face, says smiling, â€œWho is it?
author: dickens

text: Now, madam, frankly--frankness is a part of my character--shall I open the door for you?â€™  â€˜Yes, bless you, sir, for a dear creetur, and do it at once,â€™ cried Affery, â€˜for she may be a-calling to me at this very present minute, or may be setting herself a fire and burning herself to death, or thereâ€™s no knowing what may be happening to her, and me a-going out of my mind at thinking of it!â€™  â€˜Stay, my good madam!â€™ He restrained her impatience with a smooth white hand. â€˜Business-hours, I apprehend, are over for the day?â€™  â€˜Yes, yes, yes,â€™ cried Affery. â€˜Long ago.â€™  â€˜Let me make, then, a fair proposal. Fairness is a part of my character.
author: dickens

text: That I had a fever and was avoided, that I suffered greatly, that I often lost my reason, that the time seemed interminable, that I confounded impossible existences with my own identity; that I was a brick in the house-wall, and yet entreating to be released from the giddy place where the builders had set me; that I was a steel beam of a vast engine, clashing and whirling over a gulf, and yet that I implored in my own person to have the engine stopped, and my part in it hammered off; that I passed through these phases of disease, I know of my own remembrance, and did in some sort know at the time.
author: dickens

text: â€œMy friends,â€ says Mr. Chadband, â€œpeace be on this house! On the master thereof, on the mistress thereof, on the young maidens, and on the young men! My friends, why do I wish for peace? What is peace? Is it war? No. Is it strife? No. Is it lovely, and gentle, and beautiful, and pleasant, and serene, and joyful? Oh, yes! Therefore, my friends, I wish for peace, upon you and upon yours.â€  In consequence of Mrs. Snagsby looking deeply edified, Mr. Snagsby thinks it expedient on the whole to say amen, which is well received. â€œNow, my friends,â€ proceeds Mr. Chadband, â€œsince I am upon this themeâ€”â€  Guster presents herself.
author: dickens

text: Poor Tom inclined his head deferentially, but appeared to doubt that. 'I say,' repeated Mr Fips, 'that I don't know it's a matter of much consequence. The business lies entirely between yourself and me, Mr Pinch. With reference to your duties, I can set you going; and with reference to your salary, I can pay it. Weekly,' said Mr Fips, putting down the wafer-stamp, and looking at John Westlock and Tom Pinch by turns, 'weekly; in this office; at any time between the hours of four and five o'clock in the afternoon.' As Mr Fips said this, he made up his face as if he were going to whistle. But he didn't. 'You are very good,' said Tom, whose countenance was now suffused with pleasure; 'and nothing can be more satisfactory or straightforward. My attendance will be required--'  'From half-past nine to four o'clock or so, I should say,' interrupted Mr Fips. 'About that.'
author: dickens

text: This diverts suspicion and confuses it; and for the same reason I recommended that, even if you came back last night, you should not go home. It brings in more confusion, and you want confusion.â€  Wemmick, having finished his breakfast, here looked at his watch, and began to get his coat on. â€œAnd now, Mr. Pip,â€ said he, with his hands still in the sleeves, â€œI have probably done the most I can do; but if I can ever do more,â€”from a Walworth point of view, and in a strictly private and personal capacity,â€”I shall be glad to do it. Hereâ€™s the address. There can be no harm in your going here to-night, and seeing for yourself that all is well with Tom, Jack, or Richard, before you go home,â€”which is another reason for your not going home last night.

text: â€˜Wasnâ€™t that how you put it?â€™  â€˜That was what I said.â€™  â€˜Ay! But think of the whole Yard having got it. Think of their all meeting me with it, on my collecting days, here and there and everywhere. Whether they pay, or whether they donâ€™t pay. Merdle, Merdle, Merdle. Always Merdle.â€™  â€˜Very strange how these runs on an infatuation prevail,â€™ said Arthur. â€˜Anâ€™t it?â€™ returned Pancks. After smoking for a minute or so, more drily than comported with his recent oiling, he added: â€˜Because you see these people donâ€™t understand the subject.â€™  â€˜Not a bit,â€™ assented Clennam. â€˜Not a bit,â€™ cried Pancks. â€˜Know nothing of figures. Know nothing of money questions. Never made a calculation.

text: Mrs Pipchin was again beside him, if she had ever been away (he thought she had gone out with the Doctor, but it was all a dream perhaps), and presently a bottle and glass got into her hands magically, and she poured out the contents for him. After that, he had some real good jelly, which Mrs Blimber brought to him herself; and then he was so well, that Mrs Pipchin went home, at his urgent solicitation, and Briggs and Tozer came to bed. Poor Briggs grumbled terribly about his own analysis, which could hardly have discomposed him more if it had been a chemical process; but he was very good to Paul, and so was Tozer, and so were all the rest, for they every one looked in before going to bed, and said, â€œHow are you now, Dombey?â€ â€œCheer up, little Dombey!â€ and so forth.
author: dickens

text: He was so doubtful (and with justice) of his own character, that he determined not to say one word of vain regret or good resolve to Mark, but steadily to keep his purpose before his own eyes solely; and there was not a jot of pride in this; nothing but humility and steadfastness; the best armour he could wear. So low had Eden brought him down. So high had Eden raised him up. After a long and lingering illness (in certain forlorn stages of which, when too far gone to speak, he had feebly written 'jolly!' on a slate), Mark showed some symptoms of returning health. They came and went, and flickered for a time; but he began to mend at last decidedly; and after that continued to improve from day to day.
author: dickens

text: Amidst the dim and grim alleyways of London, there existed a little haberdashery known to none save those in the keenest of dispositions. The air reeked splendidly of worn leather, beeswax, and a hint of yesteryearâ€™s pipe smoke. Amidst the jumble of oddments, a solitary candle flickered, casting wandering shadows upon the stockpiles of ribbons, buttons and spools of thread. Its owner, a wide-eyed Mr. Pumblechook, scrabbled endlessly amongst his wares, with a visage of perennial bewilderment - as if each day brought forth an unprecedented inventory, though little in fact changed. The shambles of his establishment, which bore as much semblance to order as a cobweb does to a loom, was an irrefutable testament to his humble dedication to chaos. Despite the apparent disorder, a certain harmony resounded in this disarray, a melody of life and vibrancy, oft times missed in the symphony that is the bustling city of London.
author: dickens

text: In the murky light of a late London afternoon, Mr. Bartholomew Cleaver sat ensconced within the meagre confines of a musty office, poring over ledgers riddled with the testament of his numerous, dubious enterprises. The hefty, dog-eared book bore the burden of the ages, with lines layered in dust and ink; the symbols of an austere life punctuated by the relentless scratch of a quill and the hushed drone of numerals. His pale eyes, worn like two opalescent marbles scoured by the tireless tide of time, did little to illumine the gloom, their pearly lustre swallowed by the unyielding shadows. An air of relentless industry hung about him, encircling him as the thick, intertwining veins of ivy would an ancient, unyielding stone statue. Such was the existence of Mr. Cleaver, an eternally reliable cog in the ceaseless and indifferent machinery of Victorian commerce.
author: dickens

text: In the gently somber and dimly lit district of London, fringed on all sides by emerald-hued verdance that sprouted stubbornly from the cobblestones, lived a certain Mr. Thaddeus McTwain. He adorned himself in a cloak of perpetually rumpled tweed, shrouded underneath the weight of which was a body just on the scant side of emaciation, at odds with the buoyant, almost impish twinkle in his periwinkle blue eyes. Despite his gaunt stature and unfetching garb, our Mr. McTwain was a gentleman of peculiar mirth. His laughter, a cascade of sonorous chuckles, rang out over the cobbled streets and the murmur of the Thames, spreading a gentle contagion of amusement that spread through the hard Londonite hearts like a unclocked timepiece, leaving behind a trail perfumed with the sweet notes of unbidden joy.
author: dickens

text: Amid the gritty, gaslighted thoroughfares of nineteenth-century London, there inhabited a singular creature of resolute identity: a humble shoemaker named Cornelius Puddleby. His bumbling disposition belied a resolute purpose, and it seemed, dear reader, that he had been destined to forsake all worldly vanities to worship at the lonely altar of weather-beaten leather and worn-out soles. His humble dwelling, scarcely more than a cranny wedged under the symphony of commerce above, echoed the rhythm of his ceaseless workmanship. Time in his abode kept pace with the syncopation of mallet on last, fugitive wisps of time entwine themselves around scattered scraps of leather as if each was a testament to the guileless devotion of this unsung artisan. The smell of beeswax and dust hung densely around him like a mantle - a byproduct of the earthly struggle between man, time, and the imperfections of leather. Cornelius Puddleby chipped away at the benighted hours, stitching the torn fabric of London's society, one pair of shoes at the time.
author: dickens

text: In the insistent thrumming of London, where the ceaseless secret life of the city lurks behind its monotonous faÃ§ade, there dwelt a particular gentleman of sombre aspect, Mr. Edmund Crankley. With his dwelling of yesteryears confined to a narrow street behind St. Paul's, shrouded in perennial fog and perpetual gloom, Mr. Crankley was an indistinct figure immersed in the entrails of forgotten London lore. A character of stark habits, he ventured out only as the city sank into its evening shadow, prowling like the many alley cats, a phantom in top-hat and frock coat. Hardly a reassuring character to observe as the orange hues of lamplight danced on his worn visage, yet the children who dared to remain out after dark possessed a quaint fondness for this apparent stranger, as though perceiving in his melancholic demeanor an echo of their own innocence, ruthlessly trampled under the relentless march of time.
author: dickens

text: In the humble confines of a weary London alley, pressed between two crumbling brick tenements marked more by the scars of time than the hands of their erstwhile builders, dwelt a man of singular character. Mr. Ebenezer Pipp, a peculiar recluse of sorts, was as ubiquitous as the ragged cobblestones lining the street and, seemingly, just as hardworn. Much like the liniments of his watch that tirelessly ticked away the ceaseless march of time, the world moved ever onwards around this solitary figure, leaving him folded into its forgotten corners. As habitual as the extrusion of dawn from the sable night was Mr. Pipp, with his antiquated coat, weather-beaten hat, and precisely folded newspaper under his arm, inching along the familiar route to the olden coffee-shop on the corner of Elm. His countenance bore the etched lines of countless seasons, his eyes embracing a spectral mixture of wisdom and melancholy, a portal to a life lived in the shadows of the modern ebullience of London. The exquisite tapestry of life, it seemed, was sewn with characters like him â€” each a veritable stanza in the unabridged poem of existence.
author: dickens

text: In the quaint and bustling heart of London, stood an ancient establishment known far and wide as The Tickled Trout. A drinking tavern of some notoriety, it ushered promises of warmed brandy and old, comforting tales spun by tongues whimsically warmed by spirits and a roaring fire. The timbers, erratic and bent by timeâ€™s unforgiving hand, groaned with history and whispered the secrets of its many patrons. Candlelight sprawled in chaotic tendrils across the sagging rafters, casting eerie yet inviting shadows. Roaring laughter ricocheted frequently amid the rafters, like the crow cawing in the midnight moonlight, and the patrons, both from the top drawer of society and the humble pedestrian, sought solace in the intoxicating aroma of hops and barley, peas and meat pies, and camaraderie only brewed in life's grand melting pot. Every man, every woman, lost or found, prosperous or indigent, found refuge under its congenial and sagely roof.
author: dickens

text: It was upon this abominably frosty morn, a morn that seemed to sneer with a malicious glee at the plight of freezing mankind, that our dear Mr. Bumblecratch found himself perambulating aimlessly amid the fog-veiled labyrinth of London lanes and alleys. The gaslamps hung in sullen silence, their pallid glow scarcely daring to pierce the murk, illuminating nought but hunched shadows and their own tremulous reflections on the sludge-slick cobbles. The chill, it seemed, had supplanted all colour, all life and cheer with an oppressive monochrome desolation, a domain where even hope, should it ever be brave enough to visit, would shiver pitifully in lacking of a farthing's worth of warmth. Yet, surrounded by the icy swirl and the spectral gloom, Mr. Bumblecratch bore himself with an obstinate, though perhaps foolish, optimism; nestled in his threadbare coat and top hat, he was an island of human perseverance amidst a sea of desolate winter apathy.
author: dickens

text: As the candle-glow flickered and danced upon the weather-beaten walls of the humble dwelling, there, at the heart of the room, sat old Mr. Harkness, a figure as crumbled as a biscuit left too long in a cup of tea. He was a man whose face bore the harsh winters of hardship but whose eyes seemed to twinkle with an indecipherable mystery, a curious blend of wistfulness and delight. He was garbed in a misfitting suit, patched in some places, frayed in others. A fire crackled sporadically in the hob, casting wayward shadows with each erratic hiss and pop, rendering the scene before me a tug-of-war between light and shade, each vying for dominion over this cosy sanctuary. Selecting his gnarled pipe from an assortment of careworn paraphernalia, he loaded it with an experienced hand and sat leisurely to recount tales of long-dead adventurers. His voice, a lilting baritone filled with the dust of a thousand forgotten tales, battened down the hatches of that creaking ship that is the human heart, swaying uncertainly in the stinging spray of the sea that is the cruel world outside.
author: dickens

text: As the indomitable spirit of the overbearing clock struck eleven, emboldening even the meekest creature with its deep, resounding chime, debris-strewn, desolate Docktrin Street awoke from an uneasy sleep. The street, fossilized in grinding poverty and dense fog - a veritable petticoat of mystery and squalor - was home to those of unfortunate circumstances. It was known by many, desirable to nary a one. To the south, looming tall and gaunt like spectres at a banquet, stood the crumbling edifices of what was once regarded as glorious architecture, now mere sepulchres of faded grandeur. Wizened washerwomen, faces hardened by relentless hardship, leaned precariously out their murky windows, casting baleful glances towards the destitute dance of disagreeable children, their ragged costumes a sorrowful patchwork ballet amidst the cobblestones, fleeting ghosts in the brutal theatre of existence. Each window, infested with the frosty tendrils of bitter winter, served as eyes into these innumerable tales of human suffering and endurance, silently observing the tragi-comedy of life unfolding below. Thus, Dickensian London lived and sagged under the weight of a thousand desperate stories, in a hallowed opera of despair and hope, grotesque and divine, the human spirit twisted and reborn.
author: dickens

text: Upon the huddled cobblestones of Brewer's Yard, nestled between shadow and thin streams of amber lamplight, Mr. Percival Pennworthy, both percipient and punctual in his peculiar pursuits, commenced his evening's labors. A figure of self-effacing modesty, cloaked in nuances of soot and whispering fabrics, adorned by a well-worn hat that bore the weight of many an untold story. Yet beneath such stern attire, there twinkled in his eyes, a tempest of joyful defiance, darting like silvery fish beneath the moonbeam, that bespoke of an undying curiosity and an immutable spirit bound by neither law nor adage, but by the romantic pursuit of life's grandiose pageantry and incongruity, for he, dear reader, was a purveyor of knowledge, a philosopher of pavements, a seeker in the labyrinthine cityscape of humankind.
author: dickens

text: Upon the stroke of nightfall on a frigid day of wintertide, there was a narrow cobblestone alley in London, shrouded in umbral folds of darkness, scarce illuminated by the tenuous glow of distant gaslights. Winding and labyrinthian, this dim-lit artery of the city was occupied by a symphony of muffled footsteps and cries swept away by gusts of bitter cold. The icy air swirled in eddies, carrying with it a panoply of pungent odours: from fishmonger's bounty to the yeast-heavy tang of fresh bread and the pierce of chimney smoke mingling with an under-note of rusted iron. Amidst the parade of livelihood and poverty in juxtaposition under the star-spangled theatre of indigo sky, a gentleman emerged from the spectral mist -- his countenance naught but a shroud of personal melancholy. Steeped in the mournful strains of loss and laced with unseen sorrows, he journeyed forth and plunged himself deeper into the heart of this nocturnal tableau, resembling, perhaps, an ethereal ghost â€“ a spectral rambler ever cloaked in the fabric of his solitude.
author: dickens

text: 'Twas in the heart of London town, within the passworded walls of a thriving haberdashery, a milieu so overflowing with the bustling energy of commerce and the reek of wool and dyed cloths, that our scene unfolds. Here resides a man, a tailor by profession, though scarcely by passion. Mr. Edward Piddlewick: a man of considerable girth, ample spirit, and eyeglasses persistently perched on the precipice of his ruddy nose. The haberdashery, like a perpetually teetering pile of obligations, had in its employ Mr. Piddlewick, who, with his grey eyes, fought a ceaseless struggle against the tyranny of houndstooth patterns and gingham plaids, twain masters who ruled his days and haunted his nights, done in by the insurmountable reams of fabric always yet to be sewn.
author: dickens

text: In the green seclusion of a Shropshire lane, swaddled in the promise of a sun-streaked day, stood an edifice of quite modest ambition. Elm House, it was named, a dwelling of varnished oak and weather-worn stones, its features both architecturally quaint and haphazardly endearing. The cadence of Halcyon bird calls echoed through its chimney, weaving familiar notes into the silent parchment of time. Here resided Mr Cornelius Brougham, a gentleman of promising stature but decidedly less promising fortune, who was wont to spend his days unspooling reality into fanciful narratives, his dreams as strewn about as ash from his well-stoked hearth. His world resided within the crumpled pages of dog-eared books, tucked away in a world fashioned by eldritch charm and time-honoured tradition, a world over-shadowed, yet not bereaved, by the pressure of relentless modernity.
author: dickens

text: In the darkest, dampest corner of London, where respectability was as scarce as daylight, languished the inns and hovels of Grimes Street. The cobblestones, having long ago surrendered their original hue under the relentless cloak of soot, bore the sad tales of hardship with stoic silence. Equally sordid and sullen structures leaned upon one another, as if drawing their last breaths. Within such an obscure hovel lived an eccentric character, a peculiar caricature of circumstances, known only as Mr. Witherbee. Though clad in an ever-greying suit of hopelessness that carried an inexplicable weight of darker times, his eyes shimmered willfully, with the naive charm of a man untouched by the world's cynicism. A particularly curious thing about Mr. Witherbee was this - though situated haplessly amidst such squalor and decay, he bore in his heart an unyielding light and an optimism as youthful as the morning sun.
author: dickens

text: In a remote corner of England, much eclipsed by the hurly-burly of city life, there sat an elderly woman, ensconced by her hearth, whose singular gaze surveyed the world as though observing an enduring play. The timbers of her humble abode creaked, echoing quaint tales of yesteryear. Her hands, gnarled victims of inexorable time, trembled as they danced upon the aged quilt that lay upon her lap. The flickering flame in the hearth cast grotesque shadows on the walls, mirroring her life's drama, a soliloquy of solitude, and yet, a resilient spirit prevailed. Embroidered on her stern visage were the stark lines of hardship and yet, there twinkled a glimmer of joy in her blue eyes, reflecting more of life's kindness than its trials. Her world, like the drizzling rain that played a gentle sonata upon the thatched roof, was a harmonious melody of unpronounced stories- uncelebrated, yet not forgotten. Thus, in the formidable weave of man's progress, there still thrived these dim embers of a world growing old but glowing in its declining effulgence.
author: dickens

text: In the quiet corners of London, past damp, cobblestone streets and hunched, overladen lamplighters casting pools of bronze in the foggy night, old Miss Fossett resided. A woman of both marked resilience and profound eccentricities, she lived alone in a leaning, ivy-covered townhouse, forgotten by time but brimming with dusty stories. The labyrinthine hallways echoed with the distant laughter of forgotten company, framed photos smiled from wall to wall, their colours flaking off in tiny whispers of years gone by, and the worn carpets bore the impressions of a thousand invisible guests. Every tick of the grandfather clock by the hearth was a heavy sigh, the hands moving with resigned slowness as if burdened by the inexorable passage of the years; it filled the air with rippling notes, as if in among the deep, silent recesses of the old universe, time itself groaned under its roving eye. Miss Fossett's home was not simply a dwelling of antiquity; it was a chronicle of a bygone era, a testament to a London lost to the sands of time, faithfully preserved by an aging, solitary woman.
author: dickens

text: Beyond the confines of bustling London, where the quietude of the countryside manifested itself in full glory to preserve the charms of nature, resided a man esteemed for his modesty and humility. His name was Mr. Barnard. His humble abode, quaintly nestled amidst robust oak trees, was a small, half-timbered house of fond antiquity, with the finest thatched roof the rustic hands could ever festoon. Resolutely, Mr. Barnard lived a solitary life, devoid of technological intrusion, his sole meaningful companions were the melodic songs of the larks, and tales of old inscribed in his cherished, age-dusted books. His countenance, worn down by life's trials and tribulations, yet, belied none of his prevailing optimism. As obscurity of night converged, his candlelight, refusing to adhere to the surrounding envelop of darkness, emanated a steadfast glow, akin to Mr. Barnard's resilience in obstinate continuity against the adversities of the world. Thus, he carved a niche of tranquility amid the tumult of survival and celebrated the sweetness of existence, one quiet day following another.
author: dickens

text: As winter weaved its melancholic loom, begetting a thick quilt of glum grayness over the weary city of Brompton, the labyrinthine streets hummed with the plaintive cries of careworn vendors and the plaintive sighs of the diligent chimney-sweeps. Inhabiting the narrow confines of Pettigrove Lane resided one unassuming and somewhat peculiar figure, the delicate Mr. Archibald Ponsonby. Rendered tragicomic by an impoverished existence, Mr. Ponsonby was also endowed with a profound intellectual zeal concealed beneath his threadbare cloak of hardship. With rheumy eyes trained upon his thumbed and secondhand books, he would dive headlong into grand tales of sea-faring adventures, trembling at the might of leviathans, exotic isles under tropical suns, and tempestuous passions unfolded amidst the backdrop of gothic mansions. This intellectual escape was the oil to his rusted days, sustaining and nourishing his otherwise arduously barren reality. Nevertheless, the intricate tapestry of his inner life ensured Mr. Ponsonby was, at heart, a rich man in his own right, basking in the endless richness of the mindâ€™s treasury despite a world that concluded, regrettably, otherwise.
author: dickens

text: In the small, cobbled lanes of the bustling city of London sent rumbling by the ceaseless whisper of carriage wheels, there stood an edifice of great antiquity and with an aspect of threadbare elegance. The building bore an essence of grandeur strangulated by the shroud of time, burnt bricks cocooned with ivy looping between chipped stones, delicate yet defiant against the implacable march of years. Its windows, reflective in their grimy panes, gathered whispers of stories silent but palpable, whispered with fervor by the night wind. Within its looming structure, echoing with the resonance of a thousand long-dead souls resided a character as inscrutable as an unwritten book - Mister Winthrop, with his starched collar and waistcoat of faded velvet, a man who peppered his conversation with words of wisdom and a touch of rime-frost cynicism. Here, in this forgotten corner of the city, ensnared by its penny-dreadful charm, began a life intertwined with tales under layers of triumphant truths and tragic deceits.
author: dickens

text: In the sullen, gloomy alleys of the city, where prosperity seldom trod and humanity seemed extinguished, there brooded a most uncanny quiet. An iron-hearted winter reigned, commanding a vast army of frost and ice; his tyrannical might etched into the emaciated faces of the rag-clad denizens of this forgotten realm. The skeletal houses, hunched over, as if burdened by the weight of their miserable existence, held within them souls as worn and weather-beaten as the cobblestone streets they overlooked. Dimly lit by the flicker of a single candle, each narrow window seemed a vacant eye, bleary with untold stories of apparitional joy, stolen by unending despair. Amid this drear, a meagre spark of life blossomed unnoticed, a childâ€”his eyes yet unmarked by the blemishes of destitution, withheld an unquenchable curiosity - a beacon of hope in the relentless tempest of despair. Charles, they called him, an aegis of defiance against the prevailing gloom of his birthplace.
author: dickens

text: In the somber depths of London, there lay an alleyway narrow as a pin and winding like a fox's path, bearing the shadow-hinged name of Worm's End. It was the kind of nook ignored by the sun, cloistered away from the general riot of city life, yet possessed of a bustling secretive existence all its own. Gas lamps overflowed with an insubstantial, waxy glow, casting flickering shadows upon the timeworn cobblestones. Alabaster icicles hung limply from the eaves of shivering structures - half houses, half memories - while every throaty whisper and fugitive skitter portrayed the eternal striving of life beneath poverty's stern, iron-grey visage. Here, history might have lost its way, but stories, hoarded jealously in the crumbling brick hearts of edifices and the gleaming eyes of their gray and gaunt inhabitants, refused to relinquish their persistent, enduring dance.
author: dickens

text: In the sleepy hamlet of Coggleford, snuggled in the crevices of England's verdant bosom, there existed a corpulent squire by the name of Ebenezer Molesworth. Ebenezer, or to those who bore the burden of his acquaintance, 'Bloated Molesworth', was possessed of twin, bulging jowls that found permanent residence within his starched white collars, betraying an uncanny resemblance to two overripe canteloupes ensnared in a fishmonger's net. His portly figure led a hushed, unhurried existence, filling the many hours of the day with reams of crisp buttered toast, lukewarm lagers, and tomb-like tomes that chronicled in such an exhaustive fashion the overambitious exploits of Britain's bygone aristocrats. As the vestiges of sunlight cast long, tentacular shadows across the fens to herald the approach of dusk, Ebenezer would oft find himself ensconced in the comforts of his high-backed, leather armchair. His countenance, bathed in the flickering firelight, would soften into a mask of absent-minded reverie, surrendering itself to the mesmerizing dance of the flames, and the ghosts they conjured from the shadowy reaches of his memory. His heart, a heart pockmarked by the relentless hammering of time, shivered in his chest, a dutiful town crier proclaiming in solitary resonance the unspoken tales of love, loss, and languid longing.
author: dickens

text: Upon the streets of jumbled London-town, beneath the gloom of overhanging structures that bore the irrefutable, crimson stain of centuries, ambled a figure of meagre stature, yet imbued with remarkable gravity. Mr. Ebenezer Clark, a gentleman of most austere countenance, held within his gaze all the wisdom and tribulation of a life steeped in the peculiar brew of labor and solitude. His large coat, held close against the persistent London chill, was as worn as it was voluminous, speaking silently of countless seasons weathered with the stoicism of a mariner in the face of relentless storm. His stride, though deliberate, betrayed a familiar bond with adversity, each footfall reminiscent of the ticking hands of creation's great clock, unyielding and indifferent to the lives it cleaves into fragments of joy, despair and unfulfilled longing. His countenance, in the feeble light of yesteryear's lantern, seemed a carved monument to mankind's eternal struggle with fortune's mercurial temperament, reflected in the tears, the laughter, the strife, and the triumph, indelibly etched upon the tapestry of his time-worn features.
author: dickens

text: Upon the cobblestoned streets of London, beneath the glowing halo of a solitary gaslight, battled a solitary figure against the relentlessness of the frigid night. Mr. Jeremiah Bramble, a man of minuscule material fortunes but ample spiritual abundance, clutched his threadbare overcoat tighter, as if the threads could sew warmth into his chilly bones. The driving snow attempted to obliterate his trail, yet onwards he trudged, boot-heels tapping his own personal melody unto the frosted stones. His breath, a puff of transient vapour, whispered tales of enduring against the oppressive tick-tock of worldly sufferings, each frosty syllable a testament to the resilience of manâ€™s spirit amidst trials wrought by the grand tapestry of life. His eyes, pools of melancholic wisdom sheltered beneath cavernous brows, captured the scene like an oil painting bound within the museum of his memory, etched amidst a thousand others by the very quill of life's layered experiences.
author: dickens

text: As the wintry sun bore down upon the cobbled streets of London, with a tepid warmth that barely eased the chill, a man displaying a countenance as blemished as the worn brickwork of the buildings, ambled forth. Beneath the dreariness and soot that painted an unequivocal portrait of erstwhile grandeur, the faint remnants of opulence peeped from the edges. His overcoat, threadbare and unremarkable as the fog that veiled the city, bore the imprints of trials and tumults of many a year. The warped walking stick in his hand, relic of a glorious past, echoed the rhythmic music of long-forgotten prosperity. His eyes, pools of pallid grey enlivened by only the wayward spark of a memory, lingered on the spectral shadows of the passing populace. Here, amidst London's tired cobblestones and against the canvas of despair, glimmered a man, an embodiment of time and testament that whispered a tale of triumph, tribulation, and the ceaseless tick of existence.
author: dickens

text: A blustering wind wove its insidious tendrils through the narrow, cobblestone streets of London, carrying with it dregs of smoke from chimneys that staked claim to the ink-black sky. It was the sort of evening that might make a stout man contemplate the glorious indoors, the sweetness of his hearth; paradoxically, Mr. Barnaby Cratchet found himself, limned by the feeble glow of the corner lamplight, endeavoring to uphold a conversation with an odiously persistent creditor. Beneath an overhanging brow, deep-set eyes flickered nervously, mirroring the uncertain flame that struggled against the winter gusts. He resembled nothing so much as a beleaguered ship before the imposition of a furious storm, buffeted by waves of impending disaster but resolutely clinging onto the frail buoyancy of hope. Hidden deep within his threadbare coat, a letter bearing the sanguine seal of better fortunes waited silently to be revealed.
author: dickens

text: In the crooked skein of narrow lanes where the cobblestones lay as uneven as a curmudgeonâ€™s temper, a small inn named "The Magpieâ€™s Nest" perched serenely, offering solace to the weary hearts hollowed by time. Its wooden sign wore peeling paint like an old manâ€™s wrinkles, testifying years of rain and shine. Gas lamps, suspended in ghostly silence, cast a garish glow on the flute-shaped windows. Inside, a cozily humming fireplace threw lively shadows that danced a tarantella upon the timbered walls. The inn-keeper, Mr. Flewitt, a round little man with a merry pair of cheeks rosied by the generous clasp of yesteryearsâ€™ hearty laughter manifested, acted as the master of ceremonies. He stirred the cacophonous orchestra of clinking mugs, boisterous tales and the crackling fire, swirling them into a harmonious brew of camaraderie. Each patron in the Inn carried their own tales enveloped in hushed whispers of joy and sorrow, like old letters preserved in the pockets of forgotten coats, that added an ethereal character to the Magpie's Nest. Here, lost in the labyrinthine weave of London's heart, the echo of life resounded with every ticking second, writing and rewriting stories as ancient and ever-changing as the city itself.
author: dickens

text: In the mirthful rhapsodies of the waxy dawn, ensconced betwixt the serpentining play of the Thames and the imposing spectacle of Saint Paul's, the humble courtyard of Abernathy Square was quick with ceaseless motion. A coterie of chimney sweeps, their faces smudged with the sooty remembrances of their trade, danced an energetic ballet over the rooftops, and in and out of the ephemeral chimney mouthsâ€”those jagged pockets of London's heart, bleeding smoke into the morning. Down below, Mrs. Fothergill, the seller of hot sweet chestnuts, plied her merry trade amidst the clattering of horse-drawn hansom cabs and the bumbling melody of errant organ grinders. The air grew heavy with the scent of roasting street fare and the urgent clamour of competing industry, and yet, amidst the tumult, a sense of joyous camaraderie reverberated on cobblestones worn weary from centuries of footsteps - resurgent, consuming, as life itself.
author: dickens

text: In the hushed solitude of Bumbleberry Lane, an obscure sinew of London's ancient heart, the frail tendrils of dawn began to reach across the forlorn rooftops. There, tucked amidst haphazard masonry and timeworn cobble, nestled the humble abode of Uriah Scrimmages, a wizened old clerk whose rheumy eyes had long ago lost their youthful sparkle to the weariness of life. The sombre house stood, as dimly lit and whispering quiet as the man himself, a mirror to his years of quiet solitude. Somewhere in the hidden recesses of the convoluted gables, a timepiece spoke the solitary hour - a punctuated echo in the otherwise soundless inlet, bearing witness to the ceaseless march of time that had made a sunken courtyard of Scrimmages's once vibrant heart. Each gentle tick and tock that sifted through the grey veil of pre-dawn bore tidings of a new day, though for Uriah Scrimmages, the days were as alike as two peas in a pod, coming and going with the same monotonous rhythm of his existence.
author: dickens

text: In a crooked alleyway of London, serpentine and steeped in shadows, was perched the humble abode of Barnaby Drudge. â€˜Twas a dwelling of paltry proportions but steeped with conspicuous character, a spectral palette of the cityâ€™s grand narrative told in creaking timbers and time-weathered bricks. The parasitic ivy clawed upon the faded faÃ§ade, a testament to Nature's slow, insistent encroachment on the world of Man, and akin to the ivy, Barnaby too held his grip on existence, tenacious in his struggle against the ceaseless march of Time. Yet, Barnaby was no foe of Time's progress. Nay, he was its confidante, a discreet observer of its grand tapestry, cherishing with a quiet reverence the crumbling brick, the gnarled wood, the ivyâ€™s growth - the signs of life's imperfections within the perfect ballet of progression.
author: dickens

text: In the dreary depths of London, on a narrow and sombre street that had seen more prosperous times, stood an old, ramshackle house. The countless seasons had acted upon it with an impunity that left its facade pocked and faded, shutters askew like quizzical eyebrows over dust-laden windows, the bygone brilliance of its design rendered a mere jest by time's uncaring touch. The solitary lamppost that had once cast a respectable light upon its entrance rusted slowly away, ensnared in ghostly tendrils of fog that swirled and danced with a remorseless, spectral merriment. Its worn cobblestones, slick from the weeping drizzle, shined mournfully under the grudging luminescence of the moon. Nestled among the high brick walls and shadow-thrown alleyways, it hunched â€“ an embodiment of forgotten grandeur, a testament to the ceaseless wheel of change. Inside its ageing walls, tales untold unfolded, secrets whispered in hushed tones, dreams quietly birthed and mercifully stifled - a symphony of life played out in relentless rhythm to the beleaguered heart of the city.
author: dickens

text: Upon the bustling streets of London, crammed with a myriad of humanity in interminable flux, there stood a small, shabby shop, its squalid facade smeared begrudgingly by the ceaseless march of time. The shop, which bore the faded sign "J. Carraway's Fine Antiquities", emanated an aura of forlorn neglect that seemed pitifully adrift amidst the frenetic energy of the teeming city. The interior was a chaotic smorgasbord of items steeped in unknown histories, layered in dust, like forgotten legends that had crumbled into ambiguity, their tales muted beneath the dull patina of temporal decay. The proprietor, Jacob Carraway, was a man much like his shop - cloaked in the dismal grime of past years, his features etched with creases like old parchments, his piercing eyes possessing the melancholy twinkle of life's inexorable attrition. His figure, stooped under the burden of age, shuffled about the counter, his every move echoing a lifetime of unseen narratives, absorbed in the endless cavern of his solitude, a Dickensian symphony in the clamorous opera of life's theater.
author: dickens

text: Under a night-dressed sky studded with the distant flickers of indifferent stars, the dank alleyways of London wound and curled within themselves, like cryptic serpents holding close their secrets in shadowy embrace. Here, where gaslight pools found respite from their duties, a curtain of gloom hung suspended over the cobbled stones, the mist dancing in eerily silent waltzes, while the river babbling on her ceaseless course played as unseen orchestra. Homes, unseemly as a thief's conscience, lined the labyrinthine passages, their rotting timber faces lashed by years of forgotten rains and somber brick chambers playing reluctant host to a thousand whispered tragedies. Tattered lace curtains moved gently in the breeze, resembling spectral apparitions that could tell tales of misery and merriment intertwined, were they not simply inanimate relics of a bygone era. Lives stirred within these meager walls, each a story, each a testament to the paradox of human existence, a thrilling match of hopes feebly stoked and despair swiftly quenched, held captive under a dome of London's speckled void.
author: dickens

text: In the throbbing heart of London, where the clamour of commerce rings loudest and the faces of the populace parse a thousand tales of unspoken toil, resided a peculiar little haberdashery. It was a modest establishment, tucked between its bawdy, ebullient neighbours, like a reticent scholar crammed amidst brawling tavern-goers. Its timbers, groaning with age and shrouded in the veils of obscurity, lent an air of melancholy, a sigh echoing down from long-gone epochs. The owner, a wizened sage with rheumy eyes that glinted with nostalgic merriment, presided over his dominion of fripperies with a gentle dignity, his threadbare coat serving as a testament to a life donned in simple resilience. The flickering gas lamp above the door served as a beacon, luring in the curious and forsaken alike, to a haven where, for a while, they could forget the cold embrace of the foggy London streets.
author: dickens

text: In the frosted heart of the indifferent town, where wilted bricks blinked at the sky with empty eye-windows, we find our protagonist, humble Percival Pottersby. Percival was a man of sparse means and fewer words, forced into the humdrum existence of a healer of under-loved and long forgotten timepieces. His shop, a tiny shoebox domicile, was a sanctuary of solitude amidst the hubbub, tucked away in the tangled veins of the city. Thick cobwebs strung across ticking pocket watches, as if trying to capturing the fleeting time within their fraying threads. The shop breathed an air of antiquity, and under the careful observance of dusty chiming clocks, Percival tinkered away, his wiry fingers tracing the lives of these time-keepers. The heavy arm of the city rarely found its way to his corner, casting an oblivion of unwitting neglect over his professional existence, and yet, Pottersby met each crestfallen day with an unwavering perseverance, a beacon of resilience modestly illuminating the dim labyrinth of his world.
author: dickens

text: Upon the cobbled streets of London, under a sky shrouded in a veil of smog and somber grey, pattered the weary boots of Mr. Archibald Cratchit. This gentleman of tired smiles and threadbare coat, was, despite his humble circumstances, a man of considerable spirit; but he was tucked beneath the weight of his plight, like a candle flickering in the unrelenting wind. His habitation was but a meager dwelling in the heart of the city's underbelly, where destitution clung as unfairly as the frost of winter's wrath, and joy was as fleeting as the flicker of the gas lamps scornfully overlooking the shadowed alleyways. Yet one could often find in Mr. Cratchit's watery eyes an indomitable glimmer, a hint of hope burning brighter than the grandest hearth, for indeed, man's spirit can thrive even in the most despairing of circumstances, like a small flower determinedly sprouting through the sternest concrete.
author: dickens

text: Upon the detritus-littered streets of London, in the shadow of grand edifices that housed the toffee-nosed elite, lived a chronically impoverished urchin by the name of Percival Smudge. His weathered visage, shrouded in soot and the harsh cruelty of want, bore a startling resemblance to a half-forgotten sonnet, full of poignant melancholy and unspoken yearning. Percival's threadbare trouser pockets echoed the vacuity of his stomach, both being perpetually empty, a constant testament to his life, labouring with tenacious persistence within the grim theatre of existence. Against a backdrop of waning gaslight and cobblestones glazed with morning dew, the grit of life was the very essence from which Percival drew his sustenance, every struggle shaping his being, like the chisel of a sporadically merciful sculptor.
author: dickens

text: In the depth of a frost-ridden winter, there arose in a triangular lane, nestled between the snaking river and the gravel-wrought road, a modest and inconspicuous abode, affectionately christened as 'Lilac Haven' by its solitary inhabitant. The seasons had bestowed upon it a charming patina of age, the windows glowed with the warmth of a thousand fires, each brick and beam whispering tales of yesteryears. Within this domestic sanctuary, solitude thrived not as an unwelcome intruder, but as a close companion to its resident. Erebus, a subtle creature of time-worn years and many thoughts, spent his days in gentle rumination. His wrinkled countenance, etched with the indelible marks of past joys and sorrows, bore a tranquil air, as though the tumults of life had washed over him, leaving behind a sea-smoothed stone as the testament to his endurance.
author: dickens

text: Trudging along the marble-paved streets of London, ensnared in the deep pit of twilight, emerged a withered character, by the name of Ebenezer Scrooge's third cousin, twice removed, named Percival. Gaunt as a winter-bare tree and with a countenance as bleak as the foggy city streets, Percival was a man of rigid habits and parsimonious tendencies, much like his notorious cousin. His lean form, draped with a worn-out coat, shrieked of countless winters weathered alone in his frosty dwelling, sharing his solitude with the uncaring walls. Every step echoed the muted symphony of his melancholic solitude, as he pupated deeper into his chrysalis of desolation with each passing second. His haggard appearance and cold demeanor discarded him, as substantial and forgotten as a winterâ€™s breath lost in the chill wind, a man severing his own ties with the tapestry of human connection and brotherly affection.
author: dickens

text: Upon the narrow alleyway, encrusted in a patina of years' worth of wear and weather, stood the humble abode of Mr. Jeremiah Plump. A structure of meagre stature, its visage was no more distinguished than a hill of anthills, its bricks as dull and nondescript as the charmless fog that danced about the cobblestones. Yet within 'twas a shrine to unassuming virtue, of comfort wrested from scarcity and kindness carved from the hardest crags of life. Cruel gusts the night might whip against its fortitude, but its hearth, stoked diligently by Mr. Plump's resilient spirit, always overflowed with a sacrificial warmth that invited not just man but humanity itself into its sacred confines.
author: dickens

text: The hour was late, and the echoes of a day filled with the clamours of life were but faint whispers of their vibrant selves. Through the quiet, cobbled streets of London, a gentle fog made its stately progress, wrapping the city in an ethereal blanket. Present in this spectral vista was a man, a mere slip of a shadow, fragments of a smile playing idly about his lips. Mr. Cratchit, warm-hearted yet perennially beleaguered, ambled homewards, a humble lamp serving as his sole ally against the encroaching night. His threadbare coat, a testament to his austere existence, barely repelled the wan touch of the chilling wind. Yet within the depths of his weary countenance, the soft light of hope gleamed, undimmed despite the burdens of his impoverished purchase in life. It was as if he nurtured a secret belief -- a belief, dear reader, that dawn would forever vanquish the sombre reign of night.
author: dickens

text: It was upon a drenched afternoon, the skies a studied tableau of sullen greys and sulking hues, that our protagonist, a humble scribe of note named Humphrey, found himself traipsing disconsolately down the cobbled lanes of London's everyman borough. Methinks, wrapped fast within his threadbare greatcoat, his visage mirrored the very skyscape overhead, wistful in thought, haggard in appearance. Somewhere between the mournful chimneysweeps and the errant cry of a rag-and-bone man peddling his weathered wares, Humphrey's dreary eyes caught upon the fog-ridden view of the River Thames; a shimmering serpent winding its ceaseless way through this relentless metropolis. Despite the biting chill pricking at his wearied bones, he held firm in his purpose, drawn forth by an insatiable curiosity that could no more be quenched than the very river itself could be arrested in its course.
author: dickens

text: In the modest precincts of London Town, beneath the smoky plumes of chimney pots and the ceaseless clangour of the muffin man's bell, dwelt a character of remarkable wit, yet questionable fortune, known to all locals as Mr. Reginald Ferris. His abode, a timeworn residence crouched in the shadows of grander houses, was a sanctuary of stories well-lived and tales as yet untold, strewn with curiosities from the four corners of our nation and beyond. His countenance carried the patina of stretched hours and thwarted expectations, and yet his eyes shone with hope as bright as the gas lamps that lined the cobblestone lanes, offering light in times of encompassing darkness. A perpetual flicker of a smile crept at the corners of his mouth, for survival, he had learned, was not merely in the coins in one's pocket, but in the endurance to laugh in the face of misfortune and the willingness to lend a hand to another soul lost in the maze of existence.
