Unmarried she was, but her solitude was filled with a myriad of tasks that kept her world awhirlâ€”a rich tapestry of parish duties, charitable endeavors, and a mÃ©lange of various pursuits interrupted only by the regular pausing for tea, which she claimed staved off all sort of ills, earthly or otherwise. Indeed, Miss Augustine was an unwavering figure amidst the surprisingly complex social intricacies of Cranford, a lady upon whom not even the most vicious of rumors could lay a mark.
author: gaskell

text: It was the hour when the light outside was hastening to retreat, blending into the crepuscule of the dusk. The Mulberry trees, dancing gallantly in the cool evening breeze, shaded the quaint cottage, lending it an ethereal solitude, a quiet that resonated with the rural tranquillity of Hollingford. Inside, Miss Margaret, draped in her usual austere attire, remained engrossed in her letter from Reedham, her face aglow with the permutations of candlelight. But at the precise moment when the candle flickered fiercely, casting unsteady silhouettes onto the worn-out parchment, a pang of melancholy invaded her countenance. The ripened silence of the room was punctured by the ticking of the old mantel clock, its rhythm a reminder of the relentless march of time, bearing down upon the human heart, unescapable as the denouement of every earthly tale.
author: gaskell

text: Lady Eleanor sat gracious and regal in her worn yet fairly dignified armchair, a likeness of her in her prime years looked down upon the room from a portrait above the mantelpiece. Her face was weathered, reflecting the countless seasons of joy and hardship, her eyes held a concealed wisdom borne of experiencing life in its unvarnished splendour. The crackling fire danced its merry performance in the hearth, enveloping the room in comfort and reminded her of a time when such simple pleasures were enough to rekindle one's spirit. As the evening drew its orange and crimson curtains across the skyline of Milton, Lady Eleanor delved into the pages of her memory, each chapter resonating with profound lessons etched in the ink of time. She looked out at the growing dusk, reassured by the way the world changed yet never ceased in its cyclical dance, much akin to the rhythm of human existence. With an unhurried gesture, she turned the next leaf of a well-loved novel, immersing herself in an enthralling plot beside the warmth of her trusted hearth, safely nestled within the embrace of fleeting time, finding solace in the familiar embrace of solitude.
author: gaskell

text: As the sun bowed its farewell to the quaint hamlet of Hetherleigh, streaks of amber and rose erupted across the hitherto clear blue of the firmament. In its departing glory, it cast long, artsy shadows across the mossy cobblestone streets, as if promising the village's humble inhabitants reassurances of its speedy return. The cottages, a huddle of stone and odd geometry, sighed a quiet relief to the day's warmth, their small, paned windows flickering to life with the modest glow of hearth and candlelight. Within, mothers hushed their children with tender songs of yore, whilst the fathers, weary with the day's toil, sought solace in the comforting embrace of their worn but cherished armchairs. The pleasant clink-clank of dinner ware was intermingled with snippets of endearing anecdotes, soft laughter, and occasional rebukes for the playful pup under the table, creating a symphony of the banal yet profound rhythm of life, so peculiar to Hetherleigh.
author: gaskell

text: In the furthest corner of Cranford, nestled amidst the profusion of willows and oaks with emerald leaves like lacework, was the humble abode of Miss Emily Prattleton. It was a small, brick house, gracefully aging with just the right touch of ivy slightly obscuring the worn window sills. Inside its cosy interior, unchanging as the testament of time itself, the red carpeting embroidered with moss-imbued designs welcomed anyone blessed with the invitation. Miss Emily, a maiden of good-natured disposition and somewhat charming eccentricity, upheld the Cranford code of feminine decorum with a steadfast sense of responsibility. Her quaint domicile often hummed with the serene melodies of unspoken histories, tales of bonnets and lace, of tea-times and social graces. With an air of serene dignity, she watched the dim and glimmering hours pass byâ€”each tick of her grandparents' grandfather clock echoing the rhythmic hymn of a life steeped in tradition. Kingfishers flitted over the nearby brook, and the fragrant meadow flowers brushed against the soft hadows of the undergrowth, a testament to the gentle rhythms of English country existence Miss Emily cherished above all.
author: gaskell

text: Mrs. Marybeth Watkins, with her habitual grace, delicately adjusted the lace frill about her slender neck, her warm heart aflutter with melancholy anticipation for what awaited her. Her gaze lingered longingly upon the old cherry blossom trees that lined up the path to her childhood home, their tender blooms a veritable echo of lost innocence, softly swaying amidst the whispers of the wind. The old, cobweb-ridden library, the atrium adorned with china roses, and the thrumming echo of the grand piano now situated in the drawing-room, inhabited by only a wistful sense of nostalgia; they all pined for the echoes of past laughter and gayominglings that, alas, seemed forever ensnared in the annals of yesteryears. Complex and pensive, she pondered upon change - so inexorably woven with the passage of time, yet so cruelly oblivious to the sweet tranquility of dwelling continuity. Her eyes, tracing the spectral imprints of time, gleamed with a bitter yearning, memory and melancholy inextricably intertwined within her beating heart and observant eyes.
author: gaskell

text: Today beheld a flurry of activity in the unresting heart of Cranford. The autumn sun, in all its temperate mildness, streamed through the flower-parched window panes of Miss Matty's drawing-room, casting a glow upon the dust-suspending air within. The genteel enclave, usually given to peaceful stillness, was akin to a beehive, harmoniously disarrayed. The old sidetable, laden with a landscape of tea service and fresh scones, bore witness to an invasion of patronesses, drapers and various characters otherwise unseen during the meridian hours. They arrived bearing riddles wrapped in conjecture and garbed as gossip, whispers fluttered and alighted amongst the Twitter of the motley crowd. Miss Matty, typically a creature of habit and predictability, was unusually aflutter, her hands flitted about like birds ensnared, enveloped in a febrile anticipation of evening's charity ball to which Cranford had pledged its social troth.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet hamlet of Dunbridge, nestled amidst the verdant hills of Derbyshire, lived a woman of indomitable spirit, Mrs. Harriet Barnes. Her grizzled locks, worn soft and wild about her rosy cheeks, hinted not of age but of familiarity with the whims of life, which had bestowed upon her both delights and vexations in equal share. The goodwoman's hands, hardened and weathered by years of tenderness towards the village folk, were ever at the ready to offer succour to the needy, or to mend an ill-crafted hem, or to soothe a troubled child. But those eyes - pools of understanding with tinges of light that sparkled amidst the somber greys - unveiled the mind of an intellect, keen as the hawk, quiet as the fawn. Underneath her quiet bearing, encapsulated in the cavity of her modest cottage, bloomed stories of love, resilience, and unabated humanity; an existence woven from the yarn of living. Her life, as tranquil as the sylvan landscape that stretched yonder, spoke of the harmony that man and nature might achieve, were they but to live as Mrs. Barnes did, in humble consonance with the heartbeat of the earth.
author: gaskell

text: Certainly, there was no doubt that Miss Hawkins was an estimable woman of tender years, possessing much of that gentle patience and enduring resolve so characteristic of her sex. Her features reflected a certain quietude, as though she were perennially lost in profound thought, contemplating the mysteries of life, or simply pondering the most proper way of applying the wisdom proffered by her late father to the modest tasks of her daily routine. Blessed with a compassionate heart and a patient manner, she oft reticulated her time between the care of her ancient grandmother and the education of her younger siblings, divvying her love and attention amongst the wishes, whims, and necessities of her small familial universe. Her existence, in its unassuming beauty, against the backdrop of a quaint Lancastrian town, was a silent testimony to the quiet pleasures of duty, the joy found in profound simplicity - a tribute, indeed, to the graceful endurance of her estimable character.
author: gaskell

text: In the placid town of Cranford, where the genteel ostracism of modernity was held in high esteem, the sight of Mr. John Harmon, a man of some worldly means, forsooth, sent the eminent ladies of the locale into a mirthful flutter. A confluence of well-bred chatter, floated about the tea-tables, murmuring of silk and serge, and most certainly, the recondite prospect of renewed mercantile activity within their bounds. In Cranford, one's pecuniary standing was often talked of in terms of one's ability, or lack thereof, to provide an elegant tea service or adorn themselves in the latest, albeit modest, fashions. Such was their way, their culture, weaving the strands of commerce and propriety in a delicate lace of societal norms, a testament to the genteel simplicity that harked back to an England long swept into the corners of history by the relentless broom of industrialization.
author: gaskell

text: In the dim-lit parlour of the little cottage sat Miss Mary, open book upon her lap, distracted from her studies by the gentle rustling murmurs of the verdant meadow beyond her window. Her countenance, usually so composed and stalwart amidst the vigorously demanding ventures of the day, now expressed an almost child-like curiosity and wonder as she gazed longingly at the bucolic serenity outside. Her hands, once so deft at the loom and swift at her letters, were now at rest, as were her thoughts, indulging in the novel novelty of momentary respite. For the day had, at that moment, slipped beneath the oppressive cloak of obligation, to nestle comfortably in the soft folds of leisure. And in Mary's heart, the usual flutter of ambition gave way to a soothing rhythm of contentment, each beat echoing the tranquil whisper of the wind among the sun-dappled leaves, painting a poetic solace over the beautiful ordinariness of her life.
author: gaskell

text: In the tranquil hamlet of Moresby, nestled between the verdant green hills of Cumberland and the never-ending expanse of the sea, dwelt a silent observer of lifeâ€™s multitude of colours - Miss Eleanor Cray. Wretched in her solitude but nonetheless contented, she resided in a neat red-brick dwelling that peered out over the rolling dales and bustling docks. Widowed before she was truly wedded, her days were marked by the delicate rhythm of a narrow existence, a conveyance painted with the muted hues of melancholy, yet tinged often by the bordering palette of farcicality the village's idiosyncrasies presented. As the quiet mirth of daily circumstance played itself out under the broad canopy of the Cumberland sky, little did Miss Cray know that her accustomed solitude was on the brink of league with a most unanticipated convoy of change.
author: gaskell

text: In the antique village of Delamere, redolent of bygone eras, reposed a humble dwelling, canopied by ancient oak and encrusted with ivy. Bathed in morning light, it wore an aspect of modest dignity, becoming increasingly charming as you moved closer. Inside, the calm ambiance was embellished by a person of singular character, Miss Eleanor Hartley, a spinster who, despite her solitary life, possessed a joy made radiant by charity and goodwill. As she sat by the window, embroidering a dainty tapestry, her gaze occasionally forayed among the daisies and wild roses in her garden, her thoughts wending through the quiet maze of past and present, painting on her gentle face an expressive tableau of wistful reflection tinged with heartening hope. Time, it seemed, was a companion of kindness to her; for every wrinkle etched on her visage was a symbol of wisdom earned, and each silver strand in her hair was a testament to a life lived with honour, virtue, and a resilient spirit.
author: gaskell

text: He sat, sequestered within the comforting embrace of cupped palms, gazing pensively into the flickering glow of the hearth. The fire, revivified by the evening's chill, danced with a hypnotic vigour, casting a cavalcade of restless shadows that leaped and cavorted across the mottled, stone-laid walls of their quaint northern abode. The pendulum of the old grandfather clock, nestled into the corner like a towering, timeless sentinel, marked out its metronomic rhythm - a comforting echo of life's ceaseless march. As the evening's light began its gentle surrender to the onset of twilight, he found himself drifting into the realm of undisturbed contemplation, fueled by the deep melancholy that inevitably accompanies the sobering awareness our collective being is but a mere fragment of Nature's whimsical tapestry. His soul steeped in this tender loneliness, he was reminded of a tenet his well-worn heart knew all too well: that we are but ephemeral whispers breathed into existence amidst the grand symphony of creation. This narrative, engaged in perennial waltz with the efflorescence of life and the impermanence of existence, gently lulled him into a quiet remembrance of his place within the cosmos. Elizabeth Gaskell could not have crafted a more poignant moment.
author: gaskell

text: As the morning sunlight cascaded down through the tall, billowing curtains of the great bay window, it gently bathed the parlour of Miss Eleanor's mansion in a warm, glorious light. The umpteenth day in this wild expanse of Yorkshire found her pottering seemingly aimlessly amongst the cluttered piazza of antiquarian novels, lace doilies and porcelain teacups, all relics birthed from an untouched postcode of the past. But Eleanor, wild curls hanging wet from the bath and yet confined in a starchy white nightgown, was far from aimless. Her keen eyes, sharp as a newly honed knife that gleamed beneath the dawn light, flicked and danced across the weighty landscape of books splayed before her. Each was a cradle of knowledge, a beacon from the past whispering the secrets of times gone by. A soft sigh escaped thin, aged lips and, quite decisively, she dipped into the weathered sea of inked thoughts, drawn to the lure of a tale untold within the tattered, yellowing pages of an age-worn novel.
author: gaskell

text: In the quaint village of Whittingham, where the cobblestone lanes narrated tales of bygone days and the ivy-clad cottages whispered of inherited traditions, nestled the humble Retford abode. Unremarkable it might have seemed; yet, it housed within its venerable walls a world teeming with life and love--a grandmother with her endless verses of wisdom, an industrious father with his strougling trade, and young Martha hunched diligently over her spinning wheel, her dreams billowing as gently as the cotton threads she spun. One could not miss, though, the hush that pooled in the corners of the house, seeping into the silence of the night as motherless Martha silently mourned for the loving caress of a woman she barely remembered.
author: gaskell

text: In the quaint, idyllic town of Milton, where the mid-summer sun caressed the corners of rusty brick factories, humming melodies of a time slowly fading away, a young woman of rare grace and resilience, named Margaret Hale, dwelt with an incandescence bright enough to penetrate the looming shadows of industrial smog. The daughter of an eminent dissenting clergyman, her porcelain complexion was tainted not by the sooty caress of the towns, but by the disquiet of change; a change, as tumultuous as the steam engines that punctuated their lives, thrust upon them by the relentless march of time and progress. Among the looms and spindles, between the squalor and the grandeur, Margaret found herself caught in the ephemeral space where the consequence of human aspiration collided with the perseverance of the human spirit. Her voice, steady as the mill wheels, resonated with a gentleness that whispered tales of the undying English spirit, compelling the townsfolk to dance tune to this paradox of change and constancy.
author: gaskell

text: Mildred Ainsley, enfurled in her father's old cashmere shawl, moved through the dreary cobbled streets of Manchester with a quiet determination. Her heart echoed bitterly within the confines of her chest, yet held within it a glimmer of hope not yet snuffed out by the rain-soaked reality of industrial England. Under the mourning shadow of smoke-billowing factories, tired men and women shuffled past, their austere faces etched with the harsh lines of labour and despair. Deep within their eyes, a quiet resignation flickered, mirrored in the grey pallor of their worn-out garb and sallow skin. The whirr and clank of unseen machinery whispered incessantly, ebbing and flowing with the rugged rhythm of the city's soul. Yet despite the city's hardness and relentless grind, there lingered in the air a sense of immutable resilience; a gentle defiance of the human spirit etched against the bleak backdrop of coal, iron, and smoke. A spectral harmony of aspiration dancing, though myopic to those consumed by the engrained drudgery of their daily toil.
author: gaskell

text: In the small town of Bently, where the brass-bound door knockers shone with an invitation as warm as the hearts of the folks who dwelled within, lived a maiden of quiet calm and unassuming grace. Miss Mariana Hawthorne resided in the grand yet somewhat dilapidated manor at the end of Hobson's lane, an edifice that, despite its faded grandeur, was much like its inhabitants - full of character and resilient nostalgia. Life, for her, was an intricate tapestry of familiar duties and constrained etiquette, offers of marriage and societal affairs, all brushed with hues of pastoral beauty and occasional melancholy. Yet, there was a deep current of resilience in her, an inner strength concealed behind her soft hazel eyes, which made her more than an artifact of the passing times - she was an embodiment of the evolving spirit of Bently, yet unabashedly grounded in traditions that kept her tied to her roots. Each day, she sat by the archaic window, the sunlight softly painting her cheeks and making her heart yearn for a life slightly less predictable, a life not laid out as evenly as Mrs. Hargreaves' tea-set.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet corner of Manchester, nestled amidst numerous spindled factories and soot-bespeckled houses, stood Number 34 Paradise Row. Behind the modest, Gothic revival exterior lied an assortment of rooms filled to the brim with laughter, love, and hardships. Mrs. Agatha Shaw, a refined woman of delicate yet stern aspects, presided over this abode with an iron hand encased in graceful velvet. It was a place where cobbled streets whispered stories of old, the smoky chimneys conversed in coded signs, and the cotton mill hummed a symphony of muted perseverance. Existence in these quarters was a tapestry woven with threads of humble toil, binding each soul and every brick in an intricate pattern of societal intricacies and undeserved penalties, all fringed lovingly with tendrils of human resilience.
author: gaskell

text: Beneath a sky, streaked with hues of vibrant orange fading into the deepest, most silent blues, stood Highgrove Manor, a stately home set amongst the rolling hills of the quaint English countryside. 'Twas a gentle place, brimming over with genial chatter and soft, homely touches - the fragrance of baking bread, the whispery rustle of pages turned in a beloved book, the crackling warmth of a hearth fire with its teasing dance of sparks. Life here spun slower as if caught in a golden afternoon dream, tenderly unwinding in the rhythm of a simpler and calmer age. Its inhabitants, the Highgrove family, were much of the same disposition - industrious in their efforts, yet unhurried in their pace, embodying the gentle nobility of rural England. Just as the house was a part of them, they were an integral part of it - and together, they wove a tapestry of tranquil existence that defied the humdrum of the distant bustling world. Yet beneath its serenity, Highgrove Manor held secrets that tugged at its edges; whispers of love unconfessed, past wrongs unrectified, and truths unacknowledged that, if revealed, could tear the fine fabric of their quiet world asunder.
author: gaskell

text: In the impervious confines of her antiquated parlor, Miss Amelia Pennington regarded the world through spectacles that were as aged as her own singular self. She was of an era where propriety won the day and punctuality held sway over the wily ripples of time. From her perch by the window, the embroidery in her frail hands resembling a vibrant map of her existence, she witnessed the ceaseless passing of season and society. To her, modernity arrived not as an invader, but trudged hesitantly like a bashful suitor, shyly laying timid claims on the lands held sacred by tradition and time-honoured customs. Oh, how she mused over the puckish juvenility of the genera to come. In each silently drawn thread, she harboured lingering lamentations for the decorum of yesterday, and with each carefully observed stitch, she diligently wove her commentary on the world that was, the world that is, and the world that ever shall be.
author: gaskell

text: In that small northern hamlet, where the grey stone houses stood stark against the harsh winds of winter, resided our dear heroine, Miss Isabella Bennet. She was a creature of quiet perseverance, of gentle smiles like summer rain, and of a spirit woven with the vivacity of wildflowers blooming in an untamed meadow. Each day, she found fulfillment in her duties, and her pleasures were the simple kind â€“ the soft warmth of a day well spent in the company of a good book, the joyous laughter of children at play, the mellow and sweet lullabies sung at twilight by the lark. Her life, unlike the lives of her city counterparts, was not embroidered with grand soirees or filled to the brim with high finery, but it had a richness that illuminated even the drabbest of her dawns. This richness was not tangible; it could not be measured by the weight of gold or silver. Rather, it was the lingering taste of sweet contentment that painted her days in vibrant hues of unsolvable riddles and unspoken tales, of shared laughter and comforting silences, and love found amidst the mountains and dales.
author: gaskell

text: In the mellow light of softening dusk, the ancient city of Milford sprang forth from the ruins of industrial toil like a flower reborn from its quavering seed. The sprawling city had a faded grandeur to it, reminiscent of regality worn thin by the relentless hands of time. The limestone buildings, touched with an ethereal sheen, strung along the wiry streets like a string of pearls, clean and pure, their shapely silhouettes composing an architectural sonnet in the midst of a disquieting existence. Civility and charm seemed interwoven in the very fabric of the city, advocating a manner of serene refinement that was becoming an increasingly rare virtue in the modern world. Every cobbled street, every wrought iron gate, every whisper of the wind through the timeworn bricks seemed to hum sweetly of bygone eras and the ever-persistent pull of fond, much-cherished memories.
author: gaskell

text: As the advancing blush tints of autumn dawned upon the humble parish of Hemford, Mrs. Alice Clark, the doughty rector's wife, sat plying her needle upon a neat piece of embroidery while casting occasional, anxious glances out to the neatly paved streets through her quaintly embellished window. The ruddy maple leaves, ablaze with the fiesty splendour of their imminent twilight, fell steadily onto humble cobblestones, announcing subtly the unmerciful yet beautiful march of time. Her fingers fluttered rapidly and diligently with the rhythmic music of industry, inspired by an earnest devotion to her duty, yet undercut by an echo of melancholy. For Mrs. Clark was not ignorant to the mirrored reality of the frailty of human life in the cycle of the shifting seasons. Each prick of the needle through the delicate linen seemed to underscore the lingering thoughts that even the most sincere efforts are transient as autumn leaves. Her heart, much like the surrounding terrain, stood under the solemnity of the ending summer, while tentatively awaiting the unexpected possibilities of the incoming frost.
author: gaskell

text: As the dawn illuminated the cobblestone lanes of the small hamlet of Mellington, it swept over the quiet homesteads, their gabled rooftops glistening with the morning dew. Miss Constance Travers, a sprightly lady of perhaps three-and-twenty, could be seen up at the break of day, her nimble fingers engaged in the domestic affairs of her modest dwelling. A great believer in the virtue of industriousness, she maintained an air of composed dignity that was instilled by her circumstances rather than her birth. With her faded satin bonnet shielding her earnest face from the cool morning breeze and her russet curls escaping from the confines of her cap, she embodied the unpretentious beauty of a countryside damsel. The simplicity of her life, the profound tranquility, and the unvoiced aspirations -- formed subtle threads of a vibrant tapestry that would not be out of place in a scene immortalized by Elizabeth Gaskell, melodic in its ordinary rhythm, yet imbued with the intense strains of a remarkable narrative waiting to unfurl.
author: gaskell

text: Within those labyrinthine walls of Cranwell Manor that hid many an ancient secret, Mrs Amelia Pemberton had staked her desperate hold - a freckled woman that the sharp lanes of age had begun to mark in their ruthless way. Her delicate hands, more used to handling soft silks and dainty porcelain, now carried the heavy weight of stewardship, a role thrust upon her by the cruel hands of fate with the sudden demise of her beloved husband. Each creaking floorboard sang a mournful song to her, every dust-laden book a silent reminder of his erudition. She retreated often into the grand library, where the fading scent of his pipe still clung to the ancient, leather-bound books. After all, here, amidst the shifting dust motes and the long shadows cast by afternoon sunshine through stained glass windows, she somehow felt closer to the ghost of her dear Albert, and carried the burdens of the Manor with a quiet and dignified resolve.
author: gaskell

text: Dearest reader, let us behold insipid smoke darkening the skies of Marlborough Mills as it is wont to do every morn; the coal faces of workers who bear the grime and soot of ceaseless labor as they toil within the womb of the industrial beast. There, amidst the clash and clamour of tireless machinery, resides the spirit of our tale, a tale woven with threads of ambition and humility, coloured in hues of power and poverty. Our protagonist - more fragile than the humble sparrow, yet as steadfast as the stoic oak - finds herself pit against the clamorous tumult of the Mill, her heart torn betwixt the depth of her birth-right poverty and love for a man steeped in the machinery of prosperity. Fear her not being vanquished for her indomitable spirit serves as an anchor in stormy seas, her courage a vehement flame against the bitter gusts of despair. Fields of cotton and hearts of iron form the tapestry of her journey, as the wheels of industry grind on within the beating heart of Victorian England.
author: gaskell

text: In the dimly lit parlor of the quaint, weather-beaten house in the rural hamlet of Milton, a grand conversation was underway. Mr. Theodore Laurence, a stiffly upright mill owner of sharp wit and steel-rimmed spectacles, was expounding on the excellence of modern machinery, his words forming a soft, rhythmic hum in the air, much like the looms and spindles of his thriving cotton-mill. Yet, the shimmering, hazel-eyed Miss Eliza Brooke, a sempstress of exceptional talent, and the only daughter of the village vicar, was not so easily taken in by his fashion of argument. She sat across from him in her mother's embroidery chair, her dainty hands skillfully manipulating the needlework as she sought to imbue the cold logic of Mr. Laurence's pragmatism with the warm colours of human empathy, arguing with a stubborn resilience that even the most meticulously constructed machine was no substitute for the caring touch and discerning eye of human craftsmanship. Indeed, the dichotomy of their views â€“ as contrasting as the industrial gray of his suit against the delicate ivory of her gown â€“ lent a certain profundity to the gathering shadows of the fading evening.
author: gaskell

text: In the quaint, half-forgotten hamlet of Petherbridge, where cottages seemed to lean against one another for comfort like elderly sisters, and the lane twisted hither and thither as if bewitched by a mischievous fae, there abided a woman of such irredeemable spirit that her very name, Mrs. Prudence Hatterly, brought about a collective hush amongst the rustling reed grasses when spoken aloud. Wreathed in the dim half-light of the outgoing afternoon, with her hands lightly soiled from honing the ethereal beauty of her beloved rose garden, her eyes possessed a life-lived wisdom that seemed a contrast to her stalwart manner, hinting to all who dared gaze long into them, the existence of a heart both weathered and hopeful, tempered by circumstances, and illuminated by soft joys and hard-won wisdom. The hollow ring of the old church bell, resonating in the distant evening mist, played a symphony upon her perception, as if in its sound, she found consonance with the rhythm of her own existence, an existence that was stitched quite seamlessly into the very fabric of Petherbridge.
author: gaskell

text: "Miss Lydia Halliwell, slender as a reed and fair as the lily, wore her quiet bearing with effortless grace despite the cavernous mystery of the future that lay before her. She sat, enveloped by the serenity of the drawing room, contemplated the mid-morning light that danced through the lace-curtained window, a fine volume of Tennyson propped open in her gloved hands. Yet, as the clock on the mantelpiece chimed the eleventh hour, her heart quivered as the soft rustle of paper disrupted the silence. For there was an unopened letter, bearing the seal of the unknown but perhaps momentous, resting next to the battered copper inkwell, its existence a jarring testament of her impending escapade from the tranquillity of her cloistered life. Her reveries were often filled with the smoke and steam of the burgeoning factory towns that coloured the broad, distant horizons of her life, but she feared that the laced truths that the letter bore might alter the canvas of her delicately balanced world with their raw, ruthless power."
author: gaskell

text: There, beneath the bent branch of a lofty sycamore, with the dappled sunlight weaving irregular patterns upon her iron-grey gown, stood Miss Eleanor. She wore an expression of contemplative calm, her face turned towards the quaint cottage, her hands lost in the multiple folds of her gown. Two young sparrows fluttered past her, their shadows dancing upon the cobblestone pathway and whisking her thoughts back to days of youthful exuberance. Each ruffle in her dress seemed to echo with the whispers of bygone days, each stitch a testament to the austere simplicity she had chosen for herself. Life in the country, she knew, was paint-brush in the hands of an artist; each dawn was a newly painted tapestry of sounds and colours, each dusk a picturesque monument to the steady passing of time. The wind rustled through her austere hair, pulling at her bonnet, as if nature itself was attempting to coax frivolity out of the eternal spinster. But Miss Eleanor was unmoved, her gaze fixed, her spirit confoundingly solid despite the turbulence of earth and weather.
author: gaskell

text: Miss Harriet Corwin, a spinster of no certain age, inhabited the quaint but elegant house quietly tucked in the corner of Narrow Wynds, in the crumbling yet charming little corner of Beresfield. The exterior presented a picture of modest weather-worn brickwork, but within, the house was an embroidery of careful attention, serenity and delicate beauty. Harriet, a character both genteel and unassuming, carried an air of melancholy charm about her. Widely known for her aptitude with words and a mind unfailingly full of intellect, she indulged in providing unsolicited advice in matters of domestic etiquette and social airs to the younger women of town. The women were often loath to admit their enjoyment of Harriet's quaint impassioned discourses, yet they found unmistakable warmth and refined wisdom in them, much like the pervasive smell of lavender and polished old wood that clung to the very corners of her aging domicile.
author: gaskell

text: In the small hamlet of Kelton, where crooked stone cottages nestled in ravines of craggy hills, life chimed on in a rhythm as immutable as the sun's arc across the heavens. It was a place isolated from the bustling society, and as such, had fashioned its own customs and norms, unflushed by the waves of time that altered the visage of cities. Here, folks ventured to the moss-green commons under the clear azure sky to share their stories - tales of love and loss, of seasons turning, of simpler times â€“ tales that were sown into the rich tapestry of their communal existence. In this bucolic clime, where the lark's song met the morning dew with a sweet harmony known only to the country-folk, refinement did not parade in tailcoats and crinoline, rather it danced in the honest toil of their hands and the goodness cultivated in their hearts.
author: gaskell

text: In the tiny hamlet of Linden, tucked away in the placid hills of Westmoreland, lived a schoolmaster of considerable erudition and gentleness, Mr. Ezra Thompson. He was a man of some age and few words, though those he did choose were full of sagacity and kindness, which endeared him no small measure to the simple folk of Linden. His small stone house, overgrown with wild roses and ivy, stood quaintly by the hillside, overlooking the local church and the bustling brook. The days he spent in imparting knowledge to the wide-eyed children of the hamlet, and the evenings often found him, spectacles on his high-bridged nose, lost in some ancient book of tales or philosophy. Despite his profound learning, Mr. Thompson bore no air of pretentiousness. Instead, he was always humble, always mirthful, indulging in the simplest pleasures: the beauty of a blossoming daffodil, the joy of a bird's tune, the warmth of a friendly word. Indeed, his was a life punctuated by quiet dignity and gentle merriment.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet, pastoral hamlet of Mapleton, nestled amicably amidst verdant rolling hills, resided a singularly industrious gentleman of no small consequence, Mr. Edmund Baxter. A man humble in demeanour but resolute in spirit, he faithfully executed his duties as the parish clerk, a vocation he considered more sacred duty than simple livelihood. His world, measured by the tolling church bells and bounded by the neatly demarcated country lanes, was an exemplar of steadfast tradition, unsullied by the ceaseless march of progress that commanded the metropolis. In his quiet dwelling, lined with timeworn books and suffused with the scent of drying roses, Mr. Baxter pursued his modest existence, between inscribing meticulous parish records and imbibing the solemn solace of his silent studyâ€”an existence unburdened by grand ambitions, yet rich in its own peculiar quietude.
author: gaskell

text: In the quaint village of Dunbury Magna, where the winding River Avell gurgles through pastures green and the eternally-gray skies often seem reminiscent of a painter's moody palate, there resided the quiet figure of Miss Emily Winforth. An unmarried woman of a certain age, as those of a more diplomatic persuasion might kindly describe her, Emily was the daughter of the late Rector and known to all who resided in the village's ill-kept cottages. Held high in their esteem not for any grandeur of lineage, nor anything of monetary stature, but for an essence of selfless kindness, a gentle benevolence she radiated as naturally as the sun might lend warmth to the winter day. Her days were spent in care of others, offering succor to the plight of lonelier souls, her evenings in her father's once-charming abode, nestled between scriptures and letters dimmed by time, seeking comfort amongst the lyrical word of Austen and the poignant wisdom of BrontÃ«.
author: gaskell

text: In the heart of a small village, enveloped by fields effulgent with the rich yellows of harvested wheat and gorse, and bounded by the serenity of an age-old brook, nestled the humble dwelling of Mrs. Thorne. Hers was a cottage of modest pretensions, with a roof that wore a cap of moss, windows winking bright beneath the summer sun, and a garden fair with the tender ministrations of her time-worn hands. Far from the worldly bustle and urban clamour, her world revolved around hushed murmurs of desolate winds, the birds performing their merry symphonies from the forest nearby, and the rustling gossip of the leaves that bordered her sanctuary, painting her existence with hues of pastoral simplicity. And yet, beneath the tranquil surface of this idyllic milieu, existed a heart steeped in the throes of a long-concealed anguish, and a story waiting, with the patience of a daisy beneath the snow, for an understanding ear to decode its raw and intricate melody.
author: gaskell

text: Amidst the tumult and hum of the industrial town of Millbridge, nestled a quaint house surrounded by laden, antique roses with the faintest blush of pink. This abode belonged to the industrious Mrs. Harriet Hawksley, a woman of considerable spirit and shrewdness. The soft clatter of her knitting needles often blended melodiously with the harsher sounds of the continually clanging mills. With her neat cap on her graying hair and a shawl tightly wrapped around her, she'd sit by the window, her keen eyes not missing a single passage of the town's story daily unfolding before her. Despite her seemingly unremarkable existence, she was the unsung heart of Millbridge, a piece of past tranquility amid a present in unrelenting pursuit towards a nebulous future.
author: gaskell

text: In the weary heart of the old mill town of Lancashire, where the sooty edifices stood unadorned and formidable against the mist-laden sky, lived Mrs. Haleigh, a widow of some years, with a heart both large and tender. Her countenance, marred by the remorseless march of time and the hardship of northern winters, bore a soft glow, luminous with kindness. Her home, though not gifted with the ostentation of material abundance, was rich in the warmth of a mother's love, and within its walls, under the quiet luminescence of the hearth, one encountered tales of yore, bitter-sweet fragments of laughter and tears, and sincere discourse on the changing vicissitudes of life. The air, redolent with the fragrant tang of Yorkshire tea and the heady scent of wisdom, welcomed all weary souls that found their way to Mrs. Haleigh's door, embroiled as they were in the inexorable tide of industrial progress, yearning for solace in an era of unrelenting change.
author: gaskell

text: In the quietude of a small, rural village, a veil of tranquility did softly enshroud the quaint cottages, their roofs bathed in the lambent glow of the settling sun. The apricots ripening on their branches, the riots of roses contained within neat, picket fenced gardens, and the stray kittens lazily sprawling by the dew-kissed greens suggested a picture of pastoral bliss. Yet within the heart of this serene hamlet, nestled amidst such sublime beauty, lurked an undercurrent of human complexity; triumphs, struggles, and secrets too deeply woven into the tapestries of their lives. The villagers huddled by the hearths, their worn faces contesting their silences, the mantel clock, in its ceaseless rhythmic ticking, the only testimony of the multitude of stories still untold.
author: gaskell

text: Amelia Halifax stood, framed by the open, ivy-covered window, looking out onto the lush, tumbling gardens of Bellingham Manor. The rich emerald tones of the leaves danced dynamically under the lustrous, intermittent afternoon sunbeams, casting patterns that faded and flickered on the antique mahogany floors below. The gardens bore the grand serenity of an English summer afternoon, while mirroring the tumult in Amelia's somber heart. A white lace shawl, delicately shawl draped over her slender, pale shoulders, fluttered in the gentle breeze that seeped in, carrying with it the sweet, heavy scent of blooming roses and a far-off resonance of the village churchâ€™s bells. Though surrounded by eminent beauty, the salient emptiness of the manor house, echoed in the hollow timbre of the bells, struck Amelia's heart with a poignant sadness. The news of her brother, departed to India, irrevocably changing the quiet cadence of her provincial life, lay as heavy as the silence that now filled the manor's wide, echoing halls.
author: gaskell

text: Under the softened cloak of twilight, as the day ripened into evening, hues of dusk smudging the edges of the horizon, the village of Hollingford, a humble signature of human existence, seemed to dissolve into a tender dreamscape. The meandering lanes, sinewy under the quilt of shadow and fading light, were bathed in a melancholy stillness, disrupted only by the occasional shuffle of weary feet or the rustling of unseen creatures in the hedgerows. The ivy-clad cottages, their forms blurring with the encroaching night, harboured unlit windows that flickered momentarily with the passing of the last forestalled candles, revealing for a transient moment the furtive shapes of life, a silent ballet, receding into the silvery obscurity of the home's insides. Miss Matty, ensconced in the cosy simplicity of her parlour, leafed through the fragile pages of the day's correspondence with a sigh - a harmonious blend of resignation, contentment, and a touch of that perennial romantic despair - that whispered through the cloistered silence like a ghost of times long since passed.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet enclave of Cranford, the morning awoke to the harmonious song of birds, whose notes caressed the still, dew-laden air. Delicate shafts of golden sunlight pierced through the tendrils of mist that clung to the cool earth like a shingle of spun silk. In Mrs Forrester's neat parlour, behind festooned rose-patterned curtains, resided the heart of Cranford's gentle society, poised to greet the world with demure grace. The room seemed to understand its place in this world, the muted hum of its colours in splendid harmony with the refined sensibilities of its inhabitants. Mrs Forrester, as always, was ready to begin her day, her delicate hands folded snugly around the curves of her beloved china teapot, which was warming itself by the rhythmic dance of the fire. Here, in the hushed tranquillity of this unchanging world, the day unfurled like a genteel social visit, unfolding with a calm predictability that comforted its inhabitants as warmly as Mrs Forrester's esteemed variety of tea.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet stillness of the Manchester mill town, where the endless hum of industry and labour grew silent with the dying day, Miss Margaret Hartley, of a quiet and gentle disposition herself, watched the setting sun colour the smoke-filled sky with hues of manifest gold, most pronounced against the dark, gruff buildings. She found an odd tranquillity in such a sight, a mixture of harmony so beautiful yet profound that it seemed to partake of both the artist's paint and the factory's soot. Indeed, it served as a reminder of her own life in this town, where the profound struggles of humanity rarely ceased, but amidst which one could always find those shining rays of hope, love, and courage if only one chose to recognise them.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet town of Haverscroft, nestled amidst the verdant hills of Sussex, lived a woman of remarkable character named Mrs. Marianne Hawthorne. Her station in life was as ordinary as the humming bees in the local parson's lavender fields, yet her countenance was as distinguished and compelling as the nobility depicted in the stately portraits of Haverscroft Manor. Her small, unadorned cottage sat humbly at the border of the picturesque rustic township, and held within its walls a font of wisdom, affection, and tales from yesteryears. Each day, as dawn pervaded the tender Sussex skies, Mrs. Hawthorne, with her dignified bonnet and ageing shawl, embarked on her habitual sojourn into the heart of Haverscroft, greeting the daily vicissitudes with an unswerving spirit. Her daily strolls, accompanied by warm greetings from her fellow townsfolk, stirred the somber air of the hamlet and reminded them of their enduring bond of shared joys and shared sorrows, a testament of unbroken spirit amidst changing times.
author: gaskell

text: Indeed there arrived a fateful morning in the modest township of Kersley, a morning temperamentally wrought with the chill remnants of a late autumn's frost. The sun, rather feebly attempting to pierce through a brocade of thin, wistful clouds, imparted a grayish tinge to the quiet landscape. Mrs. Harriet Ellwood, the virtuous widow residing in the town's most aged mansion, spurred on with determination unbefitting her years, commenced her habitual walk to the local shop. All around her, the cobblestones whispered tales, twisting unwaveringly through a past overstepping centuries, and the houses, with their steep gabled roofs, leaned together in friendship, echoing the solidarity of a simpler era. Laden with this sense of the grandeur that aged familiarity imparts, Mrs. Ellwood's heart swelled, mingling gratitude with a touch of melancholy. For wasn't it the case that the keenest sense of love arose most poignantly in the quiet consideration of loss? And wasn't it too, similarly so that the reminisces of past splendors interspersed the present with a certain cheerless beauty? Such were her pensive musings, strung deeply with the flaws and glitters of her beloved Kersley.
author: gaskell

text: In the quiet hamlet of Chancery Wicket, where sprightly sparrows flocks amongst the weather-beaten stone cottages, there lay a hushed mystery. Herein resided Penelope Brimley, not quite unmarried but assuredly without spouse, a woman whose future was uncertain as a falling leafâ€™s landing. Her narrow life was composed largely of cloistered afternoons spent spinning yards of wool, materializing it from its raw form into something truly tangible, threads telling tales of lost years. Whispers had long since ceased, stifled by the steadfast march of time, as if the residents had collectively forgotten the despairing tragedian. Her poignant eyes, the colour of freshly turned soil after a summer rain, held a fragile resilience, the echo of a once roaring flame. Penelope, with her meager existence, bore the slight of faded youth and the mockery of inherited isolation, in the silent company of her own thoughts and the rustic melodies of nature.
author: gaskell

text: With the dawn breaking soft hints of pink on the horizon, Miss Madeline Beauchamp set forth from her humble abode situated on the fringes of the village of Silverbury. The tranquil lanes were yet to witness the bustling stirrings of life, and thanks to this most pleasant serenity, she could hear the lilting tunes of the unseen robin, merrily accompanying her on her morning stroll. Her mind, that industrious engine, was abuzz with thoughts, hopes, and occasional fear. Indeed, every so often, her heart fluttered like the mad larks in the spring, for she held an uncertain secret within its chambers. The question lingered on, whether it would turn out to be a joyful happening or merely a dreadful uncertainty was something only time could disclose. Her life, thus, was as undulating as the countryside roads she called home.
author: gaskell

text: Miss Amelia Hartwell was ever a quiet soul, resigned to a life of patchwork quilts, fragrant teas, and the indiscriminate praise boasted by her benevolent feline, Mr. Wellington. This placid existence poised on the cusp of nobility was housed within the subdued reverie of Cherrytree Manor, nestled amicably betwixt rolling groves and a river that twisted like a satin ribbon through the open-hearted English countryside. The tranquillity that hung about the manor, as soft and palpable as chiffon, was punctuated only by the distant peal of the village church's bells - a chorus that lent an alluring cadence to the lyric of her life. The wheels of time appeared to creak slower for Miss Hartwell, as if reluctant to rush her through the parchment pages of her solitary existence; yet, there was an undeniable pang within her that yearned for something more, something as elusive as a Spring morning's dew before the rise of the somnolent sun.
author: gaskell

text: In the declining light of the evening, I beheld in the farthest corner of the village, the crumbling manor. Overgrown with creeping ivies and encrusted with the inexorable passage of years, it stood there as a testament to a bygone age. Half an age seemed to echo in its silent halls and draughty corridors, brimming with tales of love and loss, of joy and sorrow. Yet, amidst its decaying grandeur, there existed a certain beauty, a ceaseless charm. It was as if each weathered stone and each mottled brick held a story, whispering secrets to the winds that stirred the overgrown foliage and blew across the desolate fields surrounding the old structure. From a distance, the manor seemed as an ethereal vision from a half-remembered dream, its memory etched in the collective essence of the villagers, spoken of with reverence and a touch of trepidation, a riveting symbol of the enduring nature of time and the inexorable march of life.
author: gaskell

text: Our young protagonist, Miss Amelia Harrington, found herself absorbed by the ceaseless whirr and hum of industrial Manchester. Perched upon a chair in the drawing room of her new domicile, staring out at the churning curl of smoke that danced from the countless chimneys, she found the view altogether startling and not at all unpleasant. It was as if the world had turned on its head and brought forth a landscape of pulsating energy, so awfully different from the bucolic serenity of her childhood hamlet. She felt an unfamiliar thrill, an excitement mixed with trepidation pacing within her, like a caged bird fluttering against its confines. Life in Manchester, she knew, would not be a stroll through the wide, wild moorland she was used to but a voyage through a wilderness of iron and stones, a tapestry woven with grit, sweat, and an unending march of progress.
author: gaskell

text: The sullen hatred of the Negroes engendered by the rabid utterances and violent conduct of the radicals among the whites is pregnant with harm to the South, and tends to summon to a resurrection the entombed savagery of some members of the race, and to dishearten others in their upward strivings. On and on I could go, showing the awful wreckage in the pathway of the Southern radical. "If the nation would ever heal this sore the radicals must be suppressed. If the Negroes attempt their undoing a feeling of racial solidarity among the whites greets them. If the North attempts it a sectional feeling is stimulated. "I come now to the one thing that will gladden the hearts of the Negroes and the nation and make secure the glory of the South.
author: griggs

text: I urge, I exhort, I beseech you, my dear boys, to think not of yourselves. Let your kingdom be within. Lead them as they ought to be led, taking no thought to your own glory. "If you heed my voice you shall become true patriots. If you disregard it, you will become time-serving demagogues, playing upon the passions of the people for the sake of short-lived notoriety. Such men would corral all the tigers in the forest and organize them into marauding regiments simply for the honor of being in the lead. Be ye none of these, my boys. May your Alma Mater never feel called upon to cry to God in anguish to paralyze the hand that she herself has trained. "Be not a burrowing parasite, feasting off of the world's raw blood. Let the world draw life from you.
author: griggs

text: "Oh, you are a daisy," said Lawson, and in his excess of joy at the prospective success of his scheme, he seized Dolly Smith about the waist and kissed her. That kiss awakened every demon in Dolly's nature. It took her mind back to the days when the blue of her sky was interwoven with the blackest of clouds, and the lightnings of trouble flashed forth therefrom, ripping open her every vein, and spilling beyond recall all the blood of her life. And she pledged in her soul, shaking like a decayed and tottering building in the grasp of the wind, to crush James Benson Lawson in her fall. CHAPTER VI. UP TO DATE ARISTOCRACY IN A NEGRO CHURCH. Erma Wysong was now happily located at Mrs. Turner's, little dreaming, innocent soul, of the motives and midnight plottings that had brought her there.
author: griggs

text: To prepare Negroes for taking care of our interests in the realms of highest thought, our racial organization must found universities, liberally endow scholarships, provide equipments for original investigations and so foster the cause of higher education that no race can boast of superior intellectual attainments. "OF MAKING MANY BOOKS THERE IS NO END." Books are the means by which each successive generation comes into possession of the best (of which the records have been kept) that was wrought during all preceding generations of human endeavor. Not only does the art of printing thus connect with all that was good in the past, but it also affords a man the opportunity of becoming a part of all that is being done in his day. In view of these considerations it is evident that a race that does not read must ever be a laggard race.
author: griggs

text: Thomas Jefferson and Abraham Lincoln said the problem was incapable of solution, that the two races could not live together on terms of equality. They were great and wise, but not infallible. With Morlene as a prize, I shall prove them wrong." Morlene, taking advantage of his abstraction, bestowed on him an unreserved look of pitying love. Dorlan looked up suddenly from his reverie, and their eyes met once more. There was no reserve now and Dorlan's joy was so keen that it seemed to pain him. Arising to go, he said: "I go from you consecrating my whole power to the task before me. Fortunate it is, indeed, for the South that she has at least one man so surrounded that he cannot be happy himself until he makes this wilderness of woe blossom as a rose. Farewell." Dorlan now left and walked slowly toward his home.
author: griggs

text: The driver came and Belton said: "Friend, here is one dollar and a quarter. It is all I have. Trust me for the balance until tomorrow." "Oh! no," replied the driver. "I must have my money to-day. I have to report to-night and my money must go in. Just fork over the balance, please." "Well," said Belton rather independently--for he felt that he now had the upper hand,--"I have given you all the money that I have. And you have got to trust me for the balance. You can't take us back," and Belton started to walk away. The driver said: "May be that girl has some money. I'll see her." Terror immediately seized Belton, and he clutched at the man eagerly, saying: "Ah, no, now, don't resort to any such foolishness. Can't you trust a fellow?" Belton was now talking very persuasively.
author: griggs

text: This was done, but while the pain was exceedingly excruciating, Belton showed no sign of feeling. "You may go now," said the doctor to his three attendants, "he is certainly dead." The men left. Dr. Zackland pulled out his watch and said: "It is now 10 o'clock. Those doctors from Monroe will be here by twelve. I can have everything exactly ready by that time." A bright ray of hope passed into Belton's bosom. He had two hours more of life, two hours more in which to plan an escape. Dr. Zackland was busy stirring about over the room. He took a long, sharp knife and gazed at its keen edge. He placed this on the dissecting table near Belton's feet. He then passed out of doors to get a pail of water, and left the door ajar.
author: griggs

text: We would expect, therefore, to find the past yet affecting the Negro, and such is indeed the case. From the year 1619 until the close of the civil war, the white people of the South held the Negroes in slavery. It is the habit of nature to confer upon a man those equalities that the better fit him for his line of work. In order to successfully hold slaves, the Southern man fostered the belief that the Negro's humanity was somehow of a different brand from his own. Having satisfied himself that essential differences existed between himself and the Negro, he was the better prepared to mete out treatment which he would have deemed outrageous if applied to himself by another.
author: griggs

text: As these "doubting Thomases" wearily plod their way through the Plan we hope that they will have ever present with them to add to their torture, the thought that they would have escaped the punishment of reading all that Dorlan wrote had they meekly accepted Morlene's verdict. As wail after wail shall arise proclaiming what dull reading the Plan makes, we shall chuckle gleefully and rub our hands joyfully, happy that those who would not take the word of our heroine have come to the end so richly deserved. Those who accepted Morlene's verdict and now read the Plan simply for the purpose of defending her from hypercritical personages are heroes indeed. For, be it remembered, it often requires more courage to read some books than it does to fight a battle. Such may be the case with Dorlan's Plan, and all have fair warning. THE AUTHOR. DORLAN'S PLAN.
author: griggs

text: If she would be of service to Harry, her train must move at a faster rate than that at which it is now traveling. CHAPTER XX. THE BYSTANDERS CHEER. From his quest of Morlene, on the morning of her escape, Harry returned to his home in a sullen mood. Morlene's lack of appreciation of his disinterested patriotism which her course revealed to him, was a blow in itself, apart from his loss of her as a wife. The fact that he had lost his wife and had not slept any during the whole night did not, however, cause him to remain away from his accustomed labor that day. Cooking his own breakfast, he ate his solitary meal and went forth to his daily task.
author: griggs

text: So, at every chance he got, he talked to the men who approached him, of virtue and integrity. He soon got the name of being a "virtuous prude" and the white men decided to corrupt him at all hazards. Midnight carriage rides were offered and refused. Trips to distant cities were proposed but declined. Money was offered freely and lavishly but to no avail. Belton did not yield to them. He became the cynosure of all eyes. He seemed so hard to reach, that they began to doubt his sex. A number of them decided to satisfy themselves at all hazards. They resorted to the bold and daring plan of kidnapping and overpowering Belton. After that eventful night Belton did no more nursing. But fortunately they did not recognize who he was.
author: griggs

text: In my capacity of a      white man I have assured Aunt Dilsy that Bud Harper shall not      be molested and have assured Mrs. Crump that it is safe for      Foresta to return. The two women are happy souls. I have      succeeded in locating Bud and Foresta and shall leave at once      for the purpose of restoring them to their families and their      friends. "My dear Norfleet, in view of the terrible way things get      twisted down here, don't you think it is an awful shame that      this weak and often hated race is denied the right of trial by      jury? "RAMON." CHAPTER XIX. _The Fugitives Flee Again._   When Bud Harper and Foresta, on the night following their elopement, returned to Almaville, Bud took Foresta by her home to break the news to her mother, leaving her at the gate, while he went to his home to tell his mother.
author: griggs

text: Belton determined to see that meeting of the faculty if it cost him no end of trouble. He could not afford, under any circumstances, to fail to see that colored man preside over those white men and women. That night, about 8:30 o'clock, when the faculty meeting had progressed about half way, Belton made a rope of his bed clothes and let himself down to the ground from the window of his room on the second floor of the building. About twenty yards distant was the "mansion," in one room of which the teachers held their faculty meetings. The room in which the meeting was held was on the side of the "mansion" furthest from the dormitory from which Belton had just come. The "mansion" dog was Belton's friend, and a soft whistle quieted his bark.
author: griggs

text: But be prepared, if he deems us unfit for so great a boon, to buckle on our swords and go forth to win our freedom with the sword just as has been done by all other nations of men. "My speech is made, my proposition is before you. I have done my duty. Your destiny is in your own hands." Belton's speech had, like dynamite, blasted away all opposition. He was in thorough mastery of the situation. The waves of the sea were now calm, the fierce winds had abated, there was a great rift in the dark clouds. The ship of state was sailing placidly on the bosom of the erstwhile troubled sea, and Belton was at the helm. His propositions were adopted in their entirety without one dissenting voice.
author: griggs

text: He looked upon the Negro as being of too conservative a mold, averse, like all primitive people, to innovations. He had given earnest study to improved methods of farming and had determined upon many changes that would dispense with much labor. He had in mind to substitute barbed wire for rail fences and thus be rid of Negro rail-splitters. Improved plows, planting, threshing and harvesting machines--in fact, the whole category of labor-saving devices for farming were to be brought into use. By thus elevating farm life from a condition of extreme drudgery he felt hopeful of securing white farm hands to take the place of Negroes. So the contemplated exodus did not in the least affect Lemuel Dalton's peace of mind. Not so with other young white men of the settlement, yet living on their fathers' places.
author: griggs

text: Tiara looked up through her tears, a few pretty locks of hair having now fallen in beautiful disorder across her brow. "Mr. Ellwood, I cannot endure the name Douglass and I cannot explain," said she. Ensal now perceived that this name Douglass had somehow made the girl's thoughts touch upon the very core of her life's troubles. "Douglass, Douglass, Douglass; no not Douglass," repeated Tiara in passionate tones, evidently trying to accept the name for Ensal's sake and yet being unable to do so. "Your name shall be Tiara Merlow," said Ensal. "Merlow--Merlow. I like that," said Tiara. "I will arrange for you to stop with Mrs. Helen Crawford," said Ensal. "Thank you," said Tiara. Tiara now arose to go, but it was evident that there was something yet unspoken.
author: griggs

text: The assigning of the thoughts of the race to the uplift of Africa, as affecting the situation in America, must be taken more as the dream of the author rather than as representing any considerable responsible sentiment within the race, which, as has been stated, seems at present thoroughly and unqualifiedly American, a fact that must never be overlooked by those seeking to deal with this grave question in a practical manner. THE AUTHOR. NOTES TO THE THIRD EDITION. 1. The present edition of "The Hindered Hand" differs from previous editions in that a review of Mr. Thomas Dixon's "Leopard Spots" appears in former editions in the form of a conversation between two of the characters of the book, whereas in the present edition the review is more fully given in an article appearing in the rear of this book after the closing of the story.
author: griggs

text: A man right here in your ward has gone astray." "Don't you compare me with that infernal scoundrel, Dorlan Warthell. He claims to be an educated man, and has deserted the Republican party. I could tear his liver out and show it to him, that I could." "I have come to talk to you about him." "If you have got any good to say of him, it's no use for you to begin. But if you can tell of any way to get rid of the scoundrel, I am with you." "Let me tell you my history," said Bloodworth. Bloodworth now assumed a piteous tone and began: "I am a Southern man. Before the war my father was rich, but would never own a slave, though he lived right in the South. "When the war broke out, we turned our back on the South and joined the Union Army.
author: griggs

text: His strong physique and reproductive powers, show that he is in the world to stay to the end of time. If, in the years to come, he adds mental to physical endowment, we may be in the lurch unless we take care of the physical side of our development. Give me your hand again, sir," said 'Squire Mullen, once more shaking hands with Lemuel Dalton. This matter having been disposed of, consideration was now given to Harry and Beulah. It was the concensus of opinion that the education which Harry and Beulah had received was mainly responsible for what the whites termed "arrogant assumption of equality." The advisability and inadvisability of educating the Negro was gone into and the conclusion reached that the only safe education for the Negro was the education that taught him better how to work.
author: griggs

text: he exclaimed in terror. Continuing to look about him fearfully, Tony approached the spot where the horse and the woman lay. By dint of hard labor, he succeeded in removing that portion of the horse that lay upon her. He was overjoyed to find from her pulse that she was still alive. "What must I do next," he said. He sat down to meditate. "I haven't yet murdered anybody and I shall not let this woman die if I can help it," he said with determination. Tony arose and, going to Mrs. Dalton, lifted her in his arms and proceeded in the direction of her home. After many pauses by the wayside for rest, he at last reached the Dalton estate. Through the window of his library, Lemuel Dalton saw his wife being brought home to him in an apparently lifeless condition.
author: griggs

text: Earl's task was comparatively easy, for Tiara had all along fully understood Ensal and felt no need of the assurances which Earl sought to bring. Earl was more than happy at the outcome of his mission, happy that he could inform Ensal that the way was now clear for him to declare himself to Tiara. We shall now follow Ensal to find out what measure of success attended his mission. CHAPTER XXXIX. _A Son of the New South._   "I understand that a few years ago a Negro man and woman were burned at the stake in this neighborhood. Would you kindly show me the place?" This request came from Ensal Ellwood and was addressed to young Maul, the attorney who had plead so earnestly for the conviction of the lynchers of Bud and Foresta. A sad look stole over young Maul's face.
author: griggs

text: *       *       *       *       *  Fully conscious of the stupendous character of his undertaking, Earl walked slowly up the walk leading to the office of the Governor of M----, a Southern state. He was steadying himself for the coming effort. When shown to the governor's office he said:  "This is the governor of the state of M----, I believe." "They say that such is the case," responded the governor, smilingly. "I am just from the North and am making a tour of the South. I am traveling _incognito_ and would like to be known to you as John Blue. As I shall broach only matters of common public interest in case you honor me with an interview, I shall be pleased to have you excuse me from making myself further known to you in a personal way," said Earl, with great affability.
author: griggs

text: At times in the past friends had hinted that the problem would derange him. "Let us serve each other," said Ensal. "I will go South and see what message I can bring back for you to carry to Eunice. I will serve you thus. While I am thus engaged there is something you can do for me. The kissing of the Rev. Percy G. Marshall by Tiara, made known to me by poor Gus Martin, caused me to abandon my purpose of seeking the hand of Tiara. I wish you to go to her, and pave the way for a visit from me.
author: griggs

text: She immediately reappeared at the door of the library and threw a kiss at Lemuel in girlish fashion and was soon mounted and riding out to get the benefit of the brisk morning air. As she saunters along, we may learn a few points in her history that bear upon the case unto which events are leading. She was born and reared in a section of the State of Maine where no Negroes whatever live. It was here that Lemuel Dalton found, wooed, and wedded her. She had read from time to time of the crimes of brutal Negroes and the summary punishments administered to them, and she had rather imperceptibly grown to regard the prevailing race type of the Negroes as being criminal.
author: griggs

text: She then told him that as he had violated the laws of organized society, which laws the Bible commanded him to obey, he ought to suffer for his crime. She told him that by going to the authorities and surrendering he would commend himself to their sympathy. She felt, too, that the Master Workman's treatment of John, if brought out in court, would serve to mitigate the heinousness of the offense in the eyes of the jury. Thus John, willing to suffer many years' imprisonment for a crime which his soul had so long since repudiated, hopeful of a merciful sentence, having faith in Erma and her friends, trusting in God, went down to the police station and electrified the nation with the full confession of his crime. He was placed under arrest and remanded to jail for trial.
author: griggs

text: Prior to the coming of Dorlan Warthell, there were many to be found in the United States who utterly despaired of a happy solution of the problem of adjusting the relations of the Anglo-Saxon and Negro races to each other on an honorable and mutually satisfactory basis, taking care the while to meet the highest demands of the present and of all future ages. Others, while not despairing, confessed that in the horizon subject to their vision not a glimmer of light appeared; confessed that they were only sustained by their general knowledge of nature's power to solve, through tears and years, all her problems. Thus, until the day when Dorlan came, Columbia sat chained on the one side by benumbing pessimism and on the other by deferred hope. Accepting the judgment of so sweet and true a soul as Morlene, it was he who solved the problem.
author: griggs

text: Of course there is no other kind of work open for her to do just now, but if she had only held herself up for two or three years, she might have gotten a school to teach when some of the other teachers died or got married. But as it is, she has just gone and ruined herself forever. Well, mamma, I promise you faithfully that while you are alive, and after you are dead, I'll starve before I bring disgrace upon the education which you and papa have worked so hard to give me. I'll never throw my education away by bending over a washtub or by moving about in a white man's kitchen. No, indeed! Depend upon that, mamma, you dear, kind mamma," said Margaret, with many an emphatic toss of her head.
author: griggs

text: For, while the claim is passionately cherished by the Negroes and is espoused with varying degrees of warmth by one section of the American whites, it is most vigorously opposed by another. OUR PROBLEM. It is our task to so utilize the forces at our command as to nullify all artificial hindrances to the development of the Negro; to remove from his soul the man-imposed fetters; to so open the way that the man with a black skin shall have his opportunities limited solely by his capacity, as is the case with those not of his color. We are to institute merit as the test of preferment; mind, as the measure of the man. To reverse the standard of measurement, to transfer it from color to culture, is our problem.
author: griggs

text: "Belton, I tell you frankly that my share in that kind of business will be infinitessimally small. But go on. Let me know the whole story, that I may know better what to think and do," replied Bernard. "Well, it is this," began Belton; "you know that there is one serious flaw in the Constitution of the United States, which has already caused a world of trouble, and there is evidently a great deal more to come. You know that a ship's boilers, engines, rigging, and so forth may be in perfect condition, but a serious leak in her bottom will sink the proudest vessel afloat. This flaw or defect in the Constitution of the United States is the relation of the General Government to the individual state. The vague, unsettled state of the relationship furnished the pretext for the Civil War.
author: griggs

text: Second after second passed, on the brief moments of time flew, while the eager eyes of the multitude were fastened on the murky waters of the river. Henry did not rise. He was dead. When it was known that life must be extinct, officers of the law rowed out to where he was last seen and fished his body out. Ensal who had followed the chase now returned to the court house. Tiara, Foresta and Foresta's mother had heard the shooting and formed an awe-struck group, fearing that something had happened and yet hoping against hope. Ensal's sad countenance told them that their worst fears were realized. "Henry is dead, mama," moaned Foresta, as she threw her arms about her frail mama's neck. "He is dead, mama; let's go home," wailed Foresta again. Ensal and Tiara returned to Mrs. Crawford's. CHAPTER VIII.
author: griggs

text: In a most unexpected manner the opportunity was to come. The medicine man near the hour of closing addressed the audience, saying: "Gentlemen, it pains me to state that our aeronaut is confined to his bed and will be unable to-night to make his customary balloon ascension and descent in the parachute. That part of our evening's entertainment must therefore be omitted, unless some one of you will volunteer to act in his stead." The last remark was accompanied with a smile, the speaker taking it for granted that no one would be willing to take the risk. "Two birds with one stone," said Dorlan. "The boys have taught this audience how to laugh. I can show them an act of bravery. One bird! "There must be a great force somewhere directing the affairs of the universe. His plannings puzzle me.
author: griggs

text: The boy then started across the street in Dorlan's direction. Dorlan ran out of his room and down the steps, reaching the door before the boy. Sure enough the telegram was for Dorlan. He snatched it from the boy and handed him a dollar. Dorlan turned to go upstairs. "Wait for your change, Mister. We don't get but ten cents extra." "Keep the dollar, lad," said Dorlan, hurrying up the stairway. Entering his room he gently laid the telegram upon the center table and stood back to gaze upon it. Dorlan could not conceive how he could endure the excess of grief if the message was unfavorable, or the excess of joy if it was favorable. Cautiously he approached the table, then seized the telegram and tore it open.
author: griggs

text: Leaning across the table, his fiery eyes glowing more fiercely than ever, he almost shrieked:  "Friend, aside from that book, knowest thou not unto what the content of the Southern policy is leading? Extinction, sir, extinction! Listen to me awhile." "One could hardly be more absorbed than I am at this moment," said Ensal, rather glad of the warmth of the discussion that took his mind somewhat away from his personal grief. "The Southern white man, when it comes to you, is a believer in caste. He believes or professes to believe that God, who created the worm and the bird, also created the Negro and the white man, and that the gulf between these respective orders of creations is just as wide in the one case as in the other. Follow this caste idea to its last analysis. The lower orders must give way to the higher.
author: griggs

text: On the day of the election his interest was so great that he got out of bed and sat at his window, eagerly scanning the faces of the voters as they went, and came from the polls, hoping, it seemed, to tell from their countenances what verdicts they were rendering. He had made arrangements with a newsboy to bring him a copy of the first "Extra" to be issued giving information as to how the conflict had terminated. At a comparatively early hour of the night the newsboy knocked on Dorlan's door. "Come in," called out Dorlan. The boy poked his head in the door, cast a quick glance about, then entered. "Here's your paper, Mister. Good news for _you_," said he, smiling as he handed the paper to Dorlan. "How do you know that it contains news pleasing to me?" inquired Dorlan, looking at the boy earnestly.
author: griggs

text: She was bubbling over with good humor and her wit and funny stories were the very life of any circle where she happened to be. She was most remarkably well-informed on all leading questions of the day, and men of brain always enjoyed a chat with her. And the children and older people fairly worshipped her; for she paid especial attention to these. In all religious movements among the women she was the leading spirit. With all these points in her favor she was unassuming and bowed her head so low that the darts of jealousy, so universally hurled at the brilliant and popular, never came her way. No one in Norfolk was considered worthy of her heart and hand and the community was tenderly solicitous as to who should wed her.
author: griggs

text: The programme of the Negro race, that must be ever kept in mind as a factor to be dealt with, is the obtaining of all the rights and privileges accorded by the State to other American citizens. 8. Acknowledgment is here made of the generous aid often extended the Negro race in its efforts to rise by the liberal element among the whites of the South. One of the most notable achievements of this element has been the manner in which they have fought off the attacks of the repressionists, directed against the education of the Negroes in the public school systems of the South, so amply provided for by the "Reconstruction" Governments. 9.
